prompt:

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Lost Ark".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Incredibly grindy game that forces players to do weekly raids with several alt characters, just to afford upgrading gear and keeping up with current content on single character. If you are not a god gamer with unlimited free time, you will never catch up to P2W whales.

Raids are unforgiving with several different bosses. A single boss fight can take up to 20+ minutes to finish, but a mistake from player can wipe the whole raid even at the very end and reset the boss. 

This can mean that even in weekly farm content it takes hours to kill a single boss. Random parties can be heavily impacted by gatekeeping, because no one wants to waste hours on old content.

There is absolutely no variation to weekly grind, you have to repeat same weekly dungeons and raids until new ones arrive.
Developer Smilegate RPG keeps introducing new item types for players to sink/sacrifice more time into upgrading, which also includes a lot of RNG.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
The 6.9 hours I have in this game are from launch. It's been 2 years and 2 months since and I have played PAYDAY 2 more than PAYDAY 3 in this time frame.

It's undoubtably a polished game. More sparkly. More detailed. In it's aesthetic and graphical spark, the gameplay falters. It just feels like a PAYDAY wannabe instead of a new game. And that's very tragic, considering PAYDAY 1 was grounded, desaturated, oppressive, yet still comical in premise and execution, while PAYDAY 2 grew from the grounded and nitty gritty into an extremely absurd, batshit insane game with crack-cocaine laced gameplay.

PAYDAY 3 has nothing to show for itself. If you want a great, fun heist game, pick up either PAYDAY 1 or 2. Not only will you find more players, you'll find a better time too.

Overkill, keep going, you all got it.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Hands down one of the best games I've played.
I'd initally picked up this game at launch, but dropped it due to the performance issues. I'd been hearing that things are way better recently, so I picked it up again. For starters, the graphics are fantastic, night city really does feel like a real city, and it's clear a lot of effort went into making it so. The combat is fun and engaging, although it does slowly become too easy even at the hardest difficulty (if you engage in all the side content). Towards the end of the game I found myself breezing through main story battles and boss encounters with ease which did make them feel slightly anti climactic. 
Now to the main highlight of the game - the story. Fantastic plot lines all round, great voice acting across the board. The game does a great job at making you feel the weight of decisions you make not only in the main story but also in the side quests which is so rare. I found myself actually deliberating before making choices and feeling hurt or at best left with a bittersweet feeling at the end of most quests.
Would wholeheartedly recommend this game.

I was looking for an open world game and this one kept popping up, even in Steam recommendations.  I gave it a try for five hours to give the game what I felt was a fair shake.  After five hours and having sat through the quite lengthy Interlude, I decided this wasn't for me and subsequently learned that Steam has a two hour maximum play time for a refund.  That's a silly restriction for a game like this.  In five hours I felt like I hardly did anything.  Well I attempted to refund it twice but Steam says no.

What put me off?  It felt more like an interactive story.  I was mostly a passenger for those five hours.  The driving on a keyboard was not good at all.  The game was quite dark, making it hard for me to figure out what was going on in combat.

Bottom line, it just wasn't for me for a number of reasons.  And now I'm stuck with it.   If you decide to try it, make sure you know that you only have two hours of story time before you're locked in to your purchase.

In any case, I went in with Steam recommendations and having read other mentions of it being an open world game but I never got that far.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".

- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
After 25 hours, I can safely say that Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game you play; it’s a place you inhabit. While the launch was legendary for the wrong reasons, the game I’m playing now is a masterclass in atmosphere, storytelling, and "style over substance" (though there’s plenty of substance here too). Night City is easily the most detailed urban environment ever put in a game. At 25 hours, I’ve stopped using fast travel. I’d rather drive my Kusanagi bike through Japantown at night, watching the neon reflect off the wet asphalt. Every district—from the corporate glitz of City Center to the rusted decay of Pacifica—feels distinct and lived-in.

Final Thought: If you’re looking for a digital playground that respects your time and offers a dark, mature story, Night City is calling. Just don't expect a happy ending—this is Cyberpunk, after all.

Score: 10/10 — Come for the neon, stay for the soul-crushing existential dread.

Review:
completion:
Waited probably 5 to 7 years for this game to come to NA. Some of the best combat any MMO has to offer. Unfortunately, it combines all of the worst traits of every other MMO:

Endless, and I mean ENDLESS chores: They absolutely designed this game to feel like a job so you will drop thousands of dollars to skip the grind.

Over a dozen difference currencies to manage: Another grind factor to encourage pay to win

Awful travel system: Limited teleporters to different regions unless you pay the monthly sub. If you don't, you have to sail, 
which is insanely boring and another obvious timegate to encourage microtransactions.

And last but not least RNG GEAR UPGRADING: The biggest offender of them all that people have reported spending thousands of dollars on. This is the core reason why the game is P2W, and it's a blatant scam.

This is absolutely my #1 biggest gaming disappointment. All I wanted was to play an MMO with engaging combat, but it simply had to be ruined by a greedy business model. I would do anything for a private server that just lets you gradually upgrade your gear guaranteed and just have fun with the bosses and raids.

After that you get hit with mountains of different currency and mechanics that cause you to brick wall, unless you either pay or wait and grind it out.

If you don't mind grinding it out over a long period of time it's possible not to get burnt out.

As someone who was burnt out I can say there are plenty of other games that provide more fulfilling content than what this has to offer.


TLDR:  Maybe play through the first continent of the game for the story, and then dump before suffering the grind and the story drop off.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Lost Ark".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
The game is essentially a daily routine simulator; you play for two hours and then run out of things to do. Unless...

Well, here's the thing: you can do dailies per character, not per account, and the materials for upgrading your gear that you obtain through daily events can be transferred between characters, allowing you to earn for your main by playing alts. The game puts you in a position where to play effectively, you need multiple characters.

Imagine doing the same thing over and over with several characters throughout the day. You can also purchase materials for gear upgrades with real currency, and the costs of upgrading are high, with a lot of RNG involved. The mechanics of this game don't make sense; it's a waste of time unless you enjoy doing repetitive tasks day in and day out on multiple characters and occasionally splurging real cash on materials that might improve your gear.

I definitely do not recommend it, even though the gameplay itself, the dungeons, and the combat feeling are decent... but how long can you keep doing the same, mundane things over and over again? :)

Review:
completion: For $80 this might not make sense, however, when you can pick it up for a few dollars at a Steam Sale this game offers a fantastic multiplayer experience. I actually enjoy the mix of maps that offer both open and closed concept fighting experiences. The guns also pack a punch and the more arcade style movement was a fun change of pace. It is not so fluid and the gunplay not so clicky to become something akin to COD given that the game still has weight to it. I think the game is over hated and I have had a lot of fun with it. At the same time the lack of a campaign and unintuitive way of unlocking guns can be a bit frustrating. At the moment though this is my favourite FPS multiplayer experience.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Now, two years later, I finally picked it up, and honestly? it’s not bad at all. The game feels solid. gunplay is responsive and satisfying, perks and builds actually matter, and the heists (especially the newer ones) are fun and well-designed. It’s not perfect, but i’ve been having a good time with it so far. But, and this is a big one, it’s still always-online, even if you’re playing solo. No real offline mode, no way to launch a heist without being connected. This has been one of the most requested features since launch, and Starbreeze keeps sidestepping it with vague answers or silence. if your internet goes out? you’re out.
Just want to play solo without worrying about servers? Too bad. It’s a shame, because the core game finally feels strong. But forcing players to always be online, especially for a game that’s so focused on solo and co-op PvE. Just feels unnecessary and restrictive.

Review:
completion:
This game was the one that made the saga explode in popularity. Ported numerous times since the 6th generation just like Resident Evil 4 it became a timeless classic that almost everyone has played at least once. This new version comes with Quality of life features just like an instant restart mission option if you fail, better aiming, better minimap and graphical options up to date. There is also the option to play with the original PS2 color palette. The story is about the murder of the MC's mother, the war between gangs and corrupt policemen. All the cars, boats, helicopters and even planes feel great to drive. There are guns for each situation and you can get better at using. I had a blast with this one and finished it in around 19 hours so if you like open worlds, driving, shooting and crime stories just get it.
[h1]9/10[/h1]

I experienced all the game breaking bugs, performance and game balance issues, etc. Fast forward to present day, I have over 550+ hours logged, completed all Steam achievements and replayed/beat the game enough times to experience every possible ending the story has to offer. My verdict?
I wish I could wipe my memory of ever experiencing CyberPunk 2077 as if I were Jim Carrey in Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind so I could live it all again. S Tier game.

You might think 'Oh if there is a gate-keeping on end contents then I will just play the game slowly'
NOPE that is not how this works.

There is gate-keeping everywhere even in lower level contents.

And the most frustrating thing about this game is that, there are SO MANY PEOPLE WHO DO NOT SPEAK ENGLISH.
English is not my first language either but why is that a problem? because if 1 person out of 8 people trolls, you will NEVER be able to complete the contents. And guess what? that troll does not speak ENGLISH!! And your 40 minutes or more just flushed down to toilet.

Maybe this kind of design for raids have worked out in Korean server where everyone speaks Korean and where people are more pressured to be prepared before they join the raid group. But it DOES NOT work out when 1/3 of population only speaks Spanish and 1/3 of population only speaks Chinese.

I don't think you have much time or you are already late to change. But you guys seriously got to start changing something. Your system was failed.

Review:
completion:
⭐⭐⭐☆☆
**“Payday 3: Fun Heists, Slow Fixes”**

Payday 3 has some great ideas — the gunplay feels solid, the movement is smoother, and when a heist actually comes together, it feels amazing. The teamwork moments hit hard, and the style is definitely there.

But the game launched missing a lot of what made Payday 2 legendary, and even now it still feels like it’s catching up. Limited content, weird progression, and matchmaking issues drag down what could’ve been a top-tier co-op heist experience.

It’s fun *when everything works*, but it doesn’t always work.

**3/5 — shows potential, has its moments, but still feels like a work-in-progress robbery.**

completion: as a first time player of this game I was at first skeptical of the all the hype it receives, thinking that a fair amount of nostalgia has to do with at least some of that hype. but to my surprise, this game surpassed my best expectations. the story, too direct on the message at times, features all the hallmarks of a good gta story: the conspircy, the absurdity, the twists, and more importantly the humor. the gameplay is a matured version of the first two titles of the trilogy and with the definitive edition's improvement on its mechanics is a great experience, even though the aircraft controls can still drive you mad at times. the graphics are great and if you are a new player like me you probably don't have a nostalgic barrier to enjoying its distinct cartoonish style. all in all this is a very enjoyable game to play.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion: Battlefield 2042 is good, stupid fun. If you are looking for a tactical shooter that accurately simulates real-world combat, this is not your game. If you are looking for fun, massive scale battles where you can blow people up with pretty much everything, this is your game. The scale is  great, the weapon and vehicle selection is the best I’ve seen in a battlefield game, and the gameplay loop is great in the core modes. Overall, I’d recommend this game to anyone looking for a dumb, fun shooter. As a completionist, however, this game is a nightmare. Many of the trophies are unnecessarily difficult, requiring hours of grinding, or even the multiple trophies in the extraction gamemode that are borderline impossible, on account of the fact that the lobbies don’t fill and the ones that do are full of cheaters. If you are trying to 100% this game, I’d suggest steering clear of 2042z

Review:
completion:
I got first time 100% in San andreas after 43 hours. Honestly i thought the definitive edition even after updates will be still a weird, unplayable and a mess just like in release day, but with that classic lighting (like from PS2), and fixed bugs (still i met some bugs but they weren't so annoying) that game comparing to OG version which of course was my childhood is still alright (not perfect like original but still ok).

The cons of that version which i experienced are planes/helicopters, that game forces you to control a plane with a mouse with holding a left mouse click. With flying vehicles i'll recommend to use a controller, because FOR ME, controlling a plane with a mouse was for me very uncomfortable and unplayable, i was get used to with number keyboard like from OG version.

Btw i have definitive edition by buying GTA+, because i can't imagine buying that game for a higher price. But after that, is still a fun game even with that "cartoonish" graphics.

prompt:
You are a regular Steam user.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
The Definitive Edition's of the 3D Trilogy get a lot of hate, these games were apparently very broken at launch. I cannot comment to how severe they actually were broken as I bought this game way after its launch. 

In my opinion this is the easiest and most accessible port of San Andreas, and it runs well for what it is. It brings a lot of quality of life improvements the game needed to bring it into a modern format for a newer audience. 

Legacy fans will stick by the original port of San Andreas for good reason, the modding scene for the TDE is non-existent which takes a lot away from the replay value and also effects how much time a player will spend on this version of the game once beating the story and 100% list.

But, if you are looking to play a more refined port of the San Andreas base game for casual reasons, this game will more than likely satisfy you.

prompt:

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Cyberpunk 2077 is a hollow, soulless game. Behind the flashy visuals is a dead world filled with lifeless, brain-dead NPCs that barely react to the player. Night City looks impressive, but it’s nothing more than a pretty shell with no depth, no emotion, and no reason to care.

The shooting is the only thing that feels decent. The weapons are fun, sure, but one good system can’t carry an entire game. Missions are repetitive, forgettable, and your playstyle is meaningless. Aggressive, stealth, it doesn’t matter the game plays the same every time.

The AI is laughably bad and constantly ruins immersion. Bugs and jank are still everywhere, animations feel outdated, and NPC behavior feels straight out of an unfinished early build. Calling this game “fixed” is a joke.

I don’t understand the praise this game gets. It fails as an open-world RPG and barely works as an action game. I won’t waste any more time on it, and I strongly do not recommend it.

Review:
completion:
GTA: San Andreas Definitive Edition is a remastered version of the beloved classic "GTA: San Andreas" game, updated with enhanced visuals, improved controls, and new features. Overall, it offers fans of the original a nostalgic trip down memory lane with modern improvements but still faces some criticisms for its visuals and occasional technical issues
I would rate "GTA: San Andreas Definitive Edition” at 7.5/10. It successfully resurrects the classic game with its familiar storyline and iconic characters, offering new audiences a chance to experience the original while providing nostalgia for fans. However, the definitive edition falls slightly short with its outdated visuals and occasional glitches, preventing it from fully living up to its potential.

Just get payday 2. This is like if call of duty had a heist mode that emulated payday 2.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Counter-Strike 2".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Counter-Strike 2 is still an amazing game at its core. The gunplay feels great, the mechanics are tight, and there’s a reason this franchise has stayed popular for so many years. When matches are clean, CS2 delivers some of the most intense and rewarding competitive gameplay out there.

That said, Premier mode at higher elo (+20k) currently has a serious hacker problem. It really hurts the experience when you’re trying to play competitively and fairly, and it can be frustrating to lose games to obvious cheating rather than skill.

If you want a more serious and enjoyable competitive experience, Faceit is highly recommended. The players are generally more committed, the level is higher, and the anti-cheat makes a big difference.

Overall, despite its issues, CS2 is still a fantastic game with huge potential. With better anti-cheat support in Premier, it could easily be one of the best competitive shooters on the market again.

Recommended – but competitive players should consider Faceit.

Review:
completion:
Hot characters, flashy raids, and interesting lore. Some of the negative feedback that I saw in the reviews mentioned gatekeeping of raids and a pay-to-win (P2W) system, so let me share my perspective on them.

Gatekeeping of raids: If you join an active guild and put in the effort to find the right people to play with, they will raid with any class you have. If you prefer not to be friends with other gamers, you can create your own raid lobby and label it accordingly, such as 'learning party' if you are just starting out or 'hw party' if you are well-experienced. You might be surprised by how many people are waiting to join you.

P2W: Frequent events, shops, and daily prizes provide a good amount for you to level up. While it might take a while, the progression is meant to be more like a 'stroll in the park.' Appreciate the quests and the storyline, farm some mokokos, and work on collecting items and enjoy the game fully.

Other than some toxic players ruining the raid, I've met really good friends through this game who are miles away from me. The new update with the Breaker is coming out soon and it will have lots of modifications to players needs and I am here for it.

Review:
completion:
I never played Payday 2, but I've enjoyed Payday 3 so far. However, I bought it on sale and I suggest you do it too.

I like the gunplay and weapons in the game. They are really satisfying to use and have a nice feel to them. Many favorites too choose from. The graphics are decent and the effects plays to the sense of chaos when going loud on heists (guns blazing). Going stealth can be very exilirating as well. Also, a decent variety of enemy types and a badass soundtrack makes it easy to recommend this game. 

However, there are some caveats to be aware off. Mainly, the lack of content (although it is getting better) and a poorly designed skilltree (they recently fixed the armour system). In summary, the game is fun but feels in the end a bit unfinished. Hopefully the developers will continue supporting the game with more content and improvements. As I understand it the game is a lot better now than 12 months ago.

completion:
I had a blast going through this game, yet it is hard to recommend. The story at times is super slow and I almost gave up, but once you reach the DLC content (which you should totally buy) the game redeems itself. The pace is not the reason I said it’s hard to recommend - it’s the fact that 5 years after release, the game is unoptimized and bug ridden. Main quests being stuck and needing to load from older saves, crashes for no apparent reason, minor yet annoying bugs all over the place. 

In the end it is a unique piece of art that I can’t not recommend, but this could’ve been a masterpiece and a GOAT.

Review:
completion:
Lost Ark: A Monotonous Journey into Imitation

Lost Ark fails to escape the trappings of tedium, offering a disappointingly linear experience that lacks innovation. The game's dull narrative feels like a checklist of clichés, and its unapologetic imitation of other Chinese games renders it a lackluster copycat. It's a cheap attempt at gaming that pales in comparison to its more creative counterparts, leaving players yearning for a more engaging and original experience. In the crowded world of gaming, Lost Ark is a forgettable footnote that falls short of capturing the excitement it attempts to replicate.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
This game is a weird mix of nostalgia and new visuals (kinda new).

it’s still San Andreas. That massive map with Los Santos, San Fierro, Las Venturas? Still iconic. The missions? Still fun. CJ? Still a legend. The world is as wild and alive as I remember—from gang wars and lowrider meets to jumping out of planes in your boxers.

Performance-wise, it’s better now after a bunch of patches, but still not perfect.

Music? Mostly intact, but yeah… some classics are gone due to licensing, which sucks. Still, the radio stations are great and totally set the vibe.

At the end of the day, I had fun. It's not the “definitive” version Rockstar promised, but if you’ve got love for San Andreas and can forgive some jank, it’s worth diving in. Just know what you’re getting: a slightly modernized classic with a few cracks showing.

completion:
The only reason anyone would play this game now is to get the cosmetics for BF6, which is what I'm doing. Good for EA/DICE getting some goodwill back. How messed up is it that we're looking EA of all companies to save FPS games?

Anyways, do not get this game. I don't know if it's an AMD issue or what but this game is constantly crashing. My friends have Nvidia and still suffer crashes but mine seem to be way more frequent. Blue screens, complete crashes, you name it and 2042 does it. Alt-tab? Crash. Watching a video on the side? Crash. It's embarrassing that a game and an anti-cheat is this unreliable. I hope it'll be more stable for BF6.

But outside of constant crashing, the game is also just not good. Open weapons feels wrong in a Battlefield game. That isn't to mention how abysmal the maps are. They are the worst part of the game. Want a map with a giant boat in the middle with sniper spots that have a complete 360 unobstructed view of the entire map and nothing else? This game has 2 maps like that. In fact, every map suffers from giant centerpiece and unobstructed sniper spot. It's terribly designed and there's only so much fun you can have on those maps.

completion:
Just completed every achievement in the game without even trying too hard ( the 25 hazard zone extractions was a grind ) but I finished everything in 160 hours just casually playing. I am a huge Battlefield fan, and when the game was first released it was super buggy and glitchy. 

But now ( 10/2/2025) honestly, it was not too bad of a game. Some of the map designs were silly, but that is over shadowed by the immense playablilty of this game. From conquest to rush, from tank to air superioirty, to hardcore, softcore, and even to hazard zone: there are so many game modes to play! 

I was a fun experience going from Battlefield 2042 to 1942 to Bf2 and so many classic maps that have been redesigned to be in the frostbite engine. I am waiting until BF6 comes out, but this is not a bad option to play until then. 

Only downside is there is no single player. But tons of Co-op and 4 man squad gameplay to run! 

I recommend playing this game.

Review:
completion:
Probably the most polished GTA from the [b]Definitive Edition Pack[/b].

I can't recall having any game breaking bugs, the game looks pretty, controls are fine, only issue with them I could give is that while playing on a controller, the lock-on aim mode would just skip over enemies which you actually want to target.

While the game is fine, probably the finest from the bundle, it's still a cash-grab. 
People did ask for a remaster of these, R* didn't do anything for a long time, and when they finally did they released them in a buggy state, with no ability to actually purchase an individual game, instead putting them all into one pricy bundle, and finally removing the old, original versions off steam, so now you need to either settle for the bundle, or go on the internet and try to find a crack of the original version.

I'd still recommend it, as long as you buy it on sale.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
GTA: Definitive Edition, a wave of nostalgia turned into a storm of a rushed product.

The initial idea of giving the trilogy a second life was great, but unfortunately for Rockstar Games, it would have been easier to entrust this task to mobile game developers rather than handling it themselves.

In the end, we’re left with a graphically subpar trilogy. The characters look very plastic, and the environment is overly bright (which was corrected in the latest patch, first released on Netflix, then much later on Steam, by the way).

We also regret that the atmosphere of the original games was not faithfully recreated.

So, who should be blamed? Rockstar for delegating to Grove Street Games, or the latter for not putting more effort into their work?

Anyway, there are still plenty of issues to fix. That said, playing the games is still possible, but you should approach them with caution if you're playing for specific reasons.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Oh, Battlefield 2042… what a disaster you started out as.

I originally bought the game on PlayStation back in 2021. While I managed to put in around 70 hours and had some fun, it was impossible to ignore how disappointing it felt. For a franchise that’s so close to my heart, it was clear that the game lacked many of the qualities that made earlier entries shine.

Recently, I decided to reinstall it thanks to a discount and some unlocks for BF6. To my surprise, much has been improved, and I ended up sinking another 60 hours into it.

The game still feels a little soulless and generic at times, but there’s definitely fun to be had. One of my favorite aspects is the sense of scale that comes with 128 player Conquest. The addition of weekly missions pushes me to experiment with different weapons and tactics, which keeps things fresh. Text and voice chat have finally been added, and some genuinely great maps too. Plus, the cringey voice lines? Gone.

Final Verdict:

Launch: 6/10

Now: 7.5/10

I’m cautiously optimistic about Battlefield 6, but I can only hope EA doesn’t crush those dreams—as they’ve done before

completion: As someone who's long been familiar with CD Projekt RED games, I was hesitant to pick up Cyberpunk 2077 because I was afraid of it's endless bugs, average storyline, and mediocre gameplay. I want to express my deepest gratitude to the developers for the truly long and lengthy work they have done on this game, and I will be eagerly awaiting the continuation of this universe in the second part of the game. Thank you for this game.

Review:
completion:
Ive only been playing this game for about a year, and I absolutely adore and love it to death. 

From the game itself, to the community creations (SFMs, cosmetics) I find a deep inspiration that no other game provides.

When I first joined, it was constantly emphasized how I was “late to the party” because this game lacks proper updates for over seven years now. But I still find myself incredibly attached and involved. TF2 is the kind of game that doesn’t need updates to live on, and is instead propelled forward by the community around it. This game has a lot of fight in it and an even bigger army of fans behind it. I hope to see it prosper on now and in the far future.

Love you all, and thanks for all the summer crates.

Review:
completion:
I cannot believe that i had completed this game 100% AGAIN but this time on Definitive Edition. This game is still the same with just some Graphic Upgrade, Waypoint & Checkpoints, so it's the gonna be the same old review, so here it is:
Ok, so i  had completed this game 100% and lemme tell you. It's very hard and it takes patience, sweat & determination to achieve it. It had it's ups and downs cause the game is pretty outdated for today's modern games. Here's the list:
1. Story was damn great. It was better than GTA V that's for sure. 
2. Some of the missions are hard but it was worth it.
3. Side missions are good and some of them are heavily hard such as Trucking (where the cops ram you in such a hard 
    way), Exports & Imports (it took me whole day since some of the cars spawn in different cities like Los Santos & Las 
    Venturas), The Chiliad Challenges (the bicycle are hard to control), NRG-500, Stadium Events (Blood Bowl & Dirt Track 
    almost made me broke my keyboard), Air Races (for me it was Barnstorming) & Unique Stunt Jumps (some of them were 
    hard to perform but i have managed it).

Review:
completion:
As a long-time fan of Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, I can confidently say this game holds a special place in my heart. I've been immersed in the streets of San Andreas since 2007, and even after all these years, it remains one of my all-time favorite games.

The recent Definitive Edition is, in my opinion, a triumph. It beautifully bridges the gap of all those years I've poured into this game, making it feel fresh and vibrant again. The updated graphics and quality-of-life improvements truly enhance the experience without losing the soul of the original.

For the new generation of gamers who haven't had the pleasure of exploring Carl "CJ" Johnson's journey, I wholeheartedly and strongly recommend Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas - The Definitive Edition. This is more than just a game; it's a piece of gaming history that absolutely deserves to be experienced in its full, revitalized glory. You won't regret it!

completion:
After two years, my perception of PAYDAY 3 has changed.
I feel that the game is, at last, reaching a good place. Starbreeze has been working hard and if they continue with their intended cadence of updates, I fully believe the game has the potential to overshadow its predecessor.
The improvement in stealth gameplay compared to PAYDAY 2 deserves special mention: it was an abysmal leap in terms of depth and mechanics, making this approach to heists much more rewarding for me personally.
There are still challenges ahead, mainly regarding long term content and the endgame progression system, but the game's foundation is excellent and the direction is correct. 
For those who gave up at launch, this is the ideal time to return or try it out. I recommend it!

completion:
[h2]💸 Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Classic[/h2]

[i][b]What I Played:[/b][/i] The Definitive Edition of San Andreas, revisiting a legendary story and world.

[b]The Good:[/b]

• A landmark in gaming history – one of the greatest open-world experiences ever.
• Story, characters, and combat are as strong as ever.
• Side content is still unmatched – from gang wars to dating to vehicle challenges.
• The soundtrack remains iconic, even with some tracks removed.

[b]The Bad:[/b]

• The PC port inherits quirks from the mobile version, simplifying things like the gym and dancing minigames for no reason.
• The camera is broken in vehicles – you can’t move it up or down without mods, which is a huge annoyance.
• Performance can be inconsistent, though not as bad as GTA III.

[b]Verdict:[/b] Worth it on Sale – San Andreas remains the best of the trilogy, even in Definitive Edition form. Still, I’d recommend playing the originals with mods if you want the true experience. For fans and newcomers who don’t mind some rough edges, this is a great way to experience a legendary game.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Any maps with timing-based obstacles is just a crapshoot. With every heist being hosted on their servers rather than one of you in the lobby, the latency is incredibly bad. I have great internet here, I can play League, Overwatch 2, no problems whatsoever. Payday 3's servers on the other hand are so bad that you can be seen by a camera, back around a corner and still have the detection counter counting up for another second. 

Then the lasers in vents, like on First World Bank for example, or the lasers to the back area in First World Bank, they will look deactivated on your screen, but because of the latency they probably aren't. Their solo beta is a start to getting back to a more stable game like Payday 2, but a locally-hosted multiplayer, like Payday 2, will be so nice to get.

It's still an alright game, but it would be so much better to have crisp responses since everything is close timings in stealth.

completion:
Got a group of idiots willing to learn? Go for it! I put a lot of time and effort into this game and I loved every moment of it. Once you finish all the raids, make all the alts, and teach a few fights here and there, it becomes tedious. The amount of homework to stay afloat and current with content takes a lot more time than I'd like, but they make all of the older content a lot easier to reach.

There's a lot of good fun that can be had with this game if you're into MMO's. The combat was a ton of fun, and the class diversity made for different experiences with each fight, but the gatekeeping to get into raids, the time it takes to try and get to new content (honing costs) are just wild if you don't have multiple characters to get gold from.

completion:
Elden Ring is a great game that actively hates you.

The map is massive, beautiful, and filled with enemies whose only purpose is to remind you that you’re bad. You walk five steps, something screams, you panic roll, and suddenly your runes are gone. Classic.

Combat feels great once you accept that dodging is a lifestyle, not a button.
Bosses are memorable, fair (mostly), and emotionally damaging (always).

NPCs speak in riddles, vanish, and later I find out I failed their quest because I didn’t talk to them on a Tuesday at 3am.

Still played for 100+ hours.
Still loading back in.
Still maidenless.

Review:
completion: GTA San Andreas has been with me since kindergarten and if I had a playtime tracker back then it would probably show 5-6k hours by now. It is one of my favourite games ever, easily in my top 5, maybe even top 3. I even remember once letting my dad try it, he got into a car and started stopping at every pedestrian crossing and patiently waited for the green light at traffic lights, which still makes me laugh when I think about it. I am not really a fan of this Definitive Edition, I think with mods the original game could look and play much better, but it was still fun to see all the old bugs and mechanics again. I bought it here and immediately tried to speedrun it because I watched a lot of Hugo One streams, he beats it in about 4 hours, my first run took around 20. Still, it was a cool experience and if I decide to speedrun it again I am sure it will be faster. Whatever you think about this version, San Andreas is a game for the ages.

Review:
completion:
Boot up Lost Ark.
Find the Ark.
Roll credits.
...
Play another 3000 hours for the hell of it.

Smilegate, AGS, Tencent, whoever's in charge of this, they don't respect your time as a player. They made it better by changing wandering merchants to stay on the map for 6 hours rather than 30 minutes, but so much of it is still toxic. Get on to do a thing, here's the list of 50 alarms of those other things you should be doing, and how about some dailies as well? Oh yeah and then there's your Una's tasks and that's already at least 3 hours every single day.

It expects you to play alts. If you're not playing alts, you're playing your main at ~70% efficiency. 

Obviously it's made so that you swipe a credit card and skip (some) of the grind. Obviously it is a means to an end. I just wish some of the things could be over faster, with not so much down-time in between. It can be fun, it's just... not a game you feel good about.

Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Played this game at launch on Xbox Game Pass, and only came back for the 2nd anniversary discount. The improvements since then are noticeable and appreciated, but even with Starbreeze’s promising direction, Payday 3 still struggles with replayability as it gets dull after just a few runs. The maps feel like a jumble of reused assets rather than the creative playgrounds of PD1 and PD2. The new Delivery Charge heist does help by adding more RNG. But at the end of the day, it’s still just another warehouse heist.

Hosting options remain barebones. There’s no way to set infamy limits or properly shape your crew, so lobbies are a gamble. Even when I set a heist to Overkill, level 1 players can still join.

Honestly, the only reason I came back to this game is cuz I had fun playing with friends and have a bit of hope that the franchise will return to its former glory. (I will surely regret it later)

Review:
completion:
Hours Played: 28.8

Review:

I bought Battlefield 2042 because I wanted to experience the future of warfare. The future, apparently, is 127 people running around like headless chickens while I get sniped from across the map by a guy named “xX420NoScopeJesusXx.”

Highlights of my career as a soldier of tomorrow:

Spawned in, immediately died to a hovercraft doing donuts on a skyscraper.

Called in a tank, crushed by my own tank. Respect the circle of life.

Tried to revive a teammate—he gave up mid-revive and bled out while staring directly into my eyes. Haunting.

Climbed a 50-story building for “tactical advantage,” got hit by a tornado, ended up in Narnia.

Discovered the wingsuit. Spent 2 hours pretending I was in Just Cause 4. Killed no one, had the time of my life.

My specialist shouted a quirky one-liner right after I got blasted by a rocket launcher. Very immersive.

The game promised “All-Out Warfare.” They delivered. Just not sure if it’s against the enemy team or my own sanity.

10/10 would get roadkilled by a flying ATV again. 🚁🚗💥

TF2 is a surprisingly social game. You make not expect much from from a shooter, but this is pretty much the only shooter i ever play because of this aspect, along with how amazing of an artstyle this game has. 

It is a massive shame Valve no longer seems to game what makes it into the game due to lack of quality control, because this was once a consistently beautiful looking game. So much love has been put into creating a world for these characters, the lore, cinematics, map visual cues.. real shame all that is now burried under this rug made of bright nonsensical cosmetics and terrible update decisions bloated with maps, taunts and cosmetics that frankly just don't fit the game..

But despite all the issues current TF2 has, i think the game offers you more than i had hoped so when i started playing. The random social interactions with strangers only using voice commands, chat or just even taunts is something you will truly not get in any other game. Genuinely

Review:
completion:
It runs surprisingly well on an old HP EliteDesk with the minimum supported CPU (i7 6700) and a modern Blackwell A2000.

It also runs on Linux Mint (notoriously one of the less optimal distributions for gaming). I achieved 40–70 FPS with DLSS and 2x frame generation using the RTUltra presets at 1080p.

However, DLSS frame generation only worked after I replaced the NVIDIA RTX/Streamline DLLs in Cyberpunk's bin/x64 folder with version 2.9.0 (available on GitHub). Before that, there were some strange stuttering,
it also fixed a bug where the game crashed on exit.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Counter-Strike 2".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Counter-Strike used to reward precision, discipline, and game sense. Counter-Strike 2 stripped a lot of that away.

The game looks better, but it plays worse. Sub-tick was sold as an upgrade, yet gunfights feel inconsistent, movement feels floaty, and spraying is less predictable. The tight, learnable mechanics that made CS great are gone, replaced with a game that feels random instead of skill-driven.

The player experience is even worse. Matchmaking is flooded with clueless, zero-fundamentals players who don’t know smokes, rotations, or basic economy. Teamplay barely exists. Ranks feel meaningless when every match is a coin flip between people who grind the game and people who treat it like deathmatch.

Valve didn’t modernize Counter-Strike — they diluted it. Instead of a high-skill competitive shooter, we got a prettier game that caters to chaos and inconsistency.

completion:
The sheer amount of content in GTA: San Andreas is crazy. 
It's actually insane to me how many things you can do when you compare it to Vice City which only came out 2 years before.
It has a great cast of characters, good dialogues and cutscenes, and of course iconic and very memorable moments. I feel like it's at that point that Rockstar really figured out the cinematic approach to their games.
GTA SA is obviously a staple of video game history and now I completely understand why it's held up to such high regard by fans of the series. It's a PS2 game though, so it can't possibly live up to modern titles in terms of moment-to-moment gameplay. But I'm glad I played it. [b]8/10[/b]

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 3/10.

- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
As a huge PAYDAY 2 fan—it's honestly one of my all-time favorite games—PAYDAY 3 was a massive disappointment for me. I was genuinely excited, hoping for a worthy successor, but what we got felt like a completely different game in the worst way.

The gameplay lost the gritty, intense vibe that made PAYDAY 2 so addicting. And the graphics… they’ve gone with this weird, almost Fortnite-like aesthetic that completely kills the atmosphere. It doesn’t feel grounded or immersive anymore—it feels cartoony and soulless.

I really wanted to love PAYDAY 3, but it just doesn’t have the charm, depth, or style that made the second game so incredible. Honestly, it feels like a step backward in almost every way.

I started a solo game and had to wait to create server. Came inside the bank and had to look for card to get iside the vault, turned out it was just laying in lobby. It was all I had to do. Then as I was moving 11th out of 12 bag server dissconected. I'd rather play Payday 2.

Now after I played all heists avaliable without dlc I can add that this game is very irritating, sometimes its looks like Payday 2 is Payday 3 sequel because some mechanics there work a lot better. They added a lot of minigames that look like taken from a web game. Payday 2 also had more gritty atmosphere sometimes it resembled a serious bank robbbery movies like Heat sometimes more action movie and even more elaborate heists in the style of Oceans 11. This game is so focused on being very modern with non-stop hacking and stealing chips or crypto wallets that it feels like an 90s hacker movie. There are some good heists I enjoyed but mostly they were easy, irritating and repetitive.

Review:
completion: Cyberpunk 2077 is a great game. It's characters are excellent, Night city is brilliant to explore. The game especially shines in showing the humanity behind its characters, especially in contrast to the corporate world in which they live. Johnny Silverhand is such an interesting addition to V's psyche, given you ultimatelty a great moral conflict as the story progresses. This is one of the few games where the side content is just as good, and sometimes even better, than the main story. If you are going to play this game, take as much time for the side content as you can, it will make the main story way more enjoyable as well.

Review:
completion: This diluted inclusion to the payday series promised innovation, but delivered disappointment. The stealth mechanics were the only upgrade done in this title, with every other factor being a direct downgrade from the previous title. If I listed the lack of content in this review it would look like a Wikipedia article of the Talmud. My greatest grievance for this game was the lack of a “pick a card” system after heisting. Something that was definitive for payday, and it’s just gone without an explanation. Same with pre-planning. Same with crime.net, although I hear they FINALLY added the OG crime.net UI back. The game looks like it was made with AI. Yeah. Don’t buy it. I wouldn’t support these devs ever again after their most recent business practice; which is a subscription system for DLC on a decade old game.

Review:
completion:
**Battlefield 2042 – The Bug-Field Experience**

Battlefield 2042 is basically a huge, shiny warzone held together with duct tape and hope. You’ll clip through walls, get launched into orbit by a friendly vehicle, and watch enemies teleport like they’re speedrunning reality.

And yet… it’s still fun. Explosions everywhere, chaos nonstop, and those moments where everything *actually works* feel incredible.

It’s messy, loud, and sometimes broken—but that’s part of the charm. 8/10, would get killed by a laggy hovercraft again.

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I finally bought the game I’d been wanting for a long time, and I honestly can’t believe what I’m experiencing. I’ve already spent over an hour just trying to get a stable and reasonable FPS, and the game still randomly drops from 60 FPS down to 20 out of nowhere.

This game is terribly optimized for PC. The fact that I’ve tried around 20 different “solutions” from YouTube videos and Google searches—each promising to make the game playable—says everything. The graphics settings barely matter at all. I can run similar games at 1440p, 60 FPS on medium settings without any issues, yet here even 1080p on low settings can’t deliver acceptable performance.

I’m extremely disappointed. I expected a lot more from this game. It’s painfully obvious that it was developed with consoles in mind and the PC version was treated as an afterthought. I checked the recommended PC requirements and my system fully meets them, but I’m not willing to waste any more time just trying to make this disappointment playable at all.

It it works for you, that's great. Doesn't work for me, and I should be the one to go around fixing the developers poor work.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Battlefield 2042 had a terrible launch and it deserved all the criticism it got but after putting in hours, I’ve come to appreciate what it eventually became. It’s not on the level of Battlefield 3 or 4 which are still my top picks but there’s a solid game buried under all that mess. The gun-play feels good, squad play can still deliver that classic Battlefield chaos and some of the updates genuinely improved the experience. It still has its flaws, like weak map design and questionable balance but if you go in with tempered expectations, there’s fun to be had. It’s not the Battlefield we wanted but it’s no longer the joke it started as.

As Battlefield 6 approaches in couple of days, 2042 is worth revisiting only if you want to appreciate how far it’s come and how far the series still needs to go.

If you don't mind grind insanity or don't care about getting the best gear, then you may enjoy this game. But I can't recommend a game that operates like this.

Review:
completion:
[b]Another successful period game released by Rockstar Games was San Andreas, the events of the 90s period and the ambience of this environment were very realistic, although the task flow and the logic of some missions are not as successful as Vice City, the general presentation and the well written characters of some characters also save the scenario missions part. The side factors, such as the fact that there are many activities in it, the side missions are generally enjoyable, the satisfactory size of the map makes the game valuable, the 2 most interesting cities of the state of California and Las Vegas are again very realistic in this game. This version has not lost much of the quality of the old one, this game promises to be the most varied of the trilogy. I encountered fewer bugs and lighting problems than in the other two games, so I was able to concentrate more on the side quests and events. The old version was a 10/10 game, and this version is a 10/9 game.

It is definitely an affordable buy during the discount period. If you are interested in the 90s, this is a production not to be missed.[/b]

That being said, I do recommend it. It's free to play and you will get a lot of enjoyment out of it. Skip this one, there are better alternatives. 
4/10

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I’m not a fan of games like GTA V that are labeled as open-world but still feel heavily restricted. In GTA V, the world is big, but most interactions feel shallow, you can drive anywhere, cause chaos, and follow the main story, but outside of that, your choices rarely matter. The city feels more like a backdrop than a place that reacts to you.

That’s why I avoided Cyberpunk 2077 for so many years. I assumed it would be the same kind of “open world for the sake of size” experience. I was wrong.

Cyberpunk’s Night City feels alive. Side quests aren’t just filler; they’re often better written than the main story in other games. Your choices actually change how characters treat you, how missions unfold, and sometimes how entire storylines end. You’re not just moving through the world — you’re shaping your version of it.

Once I started playing, I couldn’t stop. The atmosphere, the characters, and the storytelling stayed in my head even when I wasn’t playing.

It’s so cinematic and well-directed that if this game were turned into a movie, I’d watch it without hesitation.

Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
It's been about 10 years (or more) since the last time I played it. Maybe it's the improved graphics, but driving through the city for the first time in so long reminded me of the first time I got the game running back in 2005 or 2006, excited and inviting over a friend who introduced me to GTA Vice City, and the first girl I had my first romantic feelings for.

I think the graphical style is a big improvement over the original while still keeping its artistic identity and adding some variety/improvements to things like NPCs and lighting. However, some aspects feel neglected because it's basically just a graphical upscale on a different engine, and there are certain issues, like annoying stuttering, despite having a high FPS.

It's not worth it at full price—only if it's on sale for 50% off or more

After a year and a half after the release the game is still in such an unfinished state that i wouldn't even think its not in the beta. The only content so far is the easy cash grab dlc's with characters (one of which is a base heister in pd2) and two new (paid) missions. 
There are a couple of new cool ideas, but they are implemented in the worst way possible + a lot of base game mechanics from pd2 were just cut. At the same time perfectly working simplest mechanics were remade for some reason into the most awkward mess i've ever seen.
Playing these same few missions without an ounce of replayability or meaningfull progression or even a good amount of meaningful visual customization is very boring if not exhausting.
A couple of QoL changes (or community mods) that should have been here from the release would have made this piece of crap atleast somehow playeable but alas.

Seriously just play the PayDay 2 again or even PayDay the heist. Do not spend your money on this piece of regurgitated fast cash grab vomit and if you do - be sure to not play more than 2 hours so you still can return it because i cannot see this game getting the No Man's Sky treatment.

On release I could recommend this game. I had a lot of fun just playing though the base game. I never got into the end game content but it was there if I wanted to try it. 
Recently I tried Lost Ark out again. I made a new character to get a fresh start. Off the rip I noticed a scary amount of Bots. Just an amalgamation of default characters all wearing the same outfit standing in the exact same spot. I thought it might just be the the starting areas that had this. NOPE. I logged into my old main and even in the high level areas the exact same issue happening. Just having this many bots standing around is enough for me to say 'nope, I'm not playing' but to add, the bots also hurt the economy of the game, so even if I did play, I get to look forward to a jumbled mess of an economy when I do get to endgame. 
RIP Lost Ark.

Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers

Review:
completion:
While far from flawless, I enjoyed my time with this version of San Andreas.

Yes, it is disgusting that we had to lose the version I had already paid for, but that is a publisher failing, not the fault of the game itself.

Likewise, while the mission checkpoint system is very welcome, other weird decisions were made to change aspects of the game. Don't be surprised if the new form of lock-on system gets you killed more than once...thanks game, I totally wanted to aim for the guy behind me and not the dozen Ballas running at me with AKs...

That said, it is very good to be back in San Andreas and playing these missions, because even now it is among the finest of RPGs I've ever played. Real progression, real choice and agency...most modern RPGs pale compared to this game, even now.

Once again, I don't like that we had to have the "non-definitive" edition become unpurchaseable and nearly unplayable, but it is very welcome to come back to San Andreas, nonetheless.

Guidelines:

Review:
completion:
Overall, the game runs well on my PC, but that is where the positives end. The constant need to reinstall the game is unacceptable, and I’ve repeatedly been prevented from progressing through the story due to severe technical issues. Multiple save files have crashed and become completely unusable, including older saves, effectively erasing hours of progress.

I’ve spent nearly 20 hours replaying the first and second acts across three separate saves, only to hit the same game-breaking issue every time. The game consistently freezes and flatlines during the Silverhand bomb mission, making further progress impossible regardless of the save used.

While there is clearly a good game underneath, its extreme instability completely undermines the experience. At its current state, I cannot recommend it. Enjoyment means very little when the game is fundamentally unreliable and unable to function as expected.

This situation has essentially rendered my account unusable, as I'm missing items crucial for progression. Nonetheless, Lost Ark is still a captivating game that can consume a lot of your time, as long as you avoid making the same mistakes I did.

One of the best games I have ever played.

The heroes (playable characters) are unlocked from the beginning & each of them have unique skills. It is the same map for every game but each game fells different. The different hero combos, item builds, laning strategies make each game really fun & unique. The tutorials make the basic mechanics easy to understand.

But this game is only recommended for those with great patience, time, energy & good multitasking skills. It takes time to master. It has a fairly steep learning curve but can be enjoyed by all. The community can be toxic & stupid sometimes.

The game gets regular balance changes.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Payday 3 feels like slipping the old clown mask back on and remembering exactly why you started robbing banks in the first place—only now everything’s shinier, meaner, and just chaotic enough to make your palms sweat. The heists hit hard, the gunplay is crisp, and when a plan actually comes together you feel like a criminal mastermind… right up until the cops show up with enough firepower to level a small city.

Yeah, the game doesn’t have a ton of support right now, and it’s definitely been a rough ride at times. Matchmaking can get messy, and sometimes it feels like the game is allergic to letting you into a lobby. But once you’re in? Pure, beautiful mayhem. Lasers, loot bags, hostages screaming, alarms blaring—chef’s kiss.

Despite the rocky support, I’m still genuinely excited to see what they’ve got planned next. There’s a solid foundation here, and if they build on it even half as well as the chaos deserves, Payday 3 could end up being something wild.

Review:
completion:
What I love about Cyberpunk 2077 is the story and the way the world pulls you in. Night City feels alive in a way that is hard to explain. You are not just following a main quest. You are listening to conversations. Reading messages. Stumbling into side stories that feel personal and sometimes uncomfortable. The game rewards slowing down and paying attention more than rushing from objective to objective.

I also love how open it all feels. You can get lost in the city without feeling like you are playing it wrong. Some nights you follow the story. Other times you just drive, explore, or take on a small job that turns into something bigger. The game is at its best when you let go of the need to complete everything and just exist in the world for a while.

ive never reviewed anything so dont take this one lightly, im only doing this in the hopes it saves even one person from wasting more than 2 hours on this game never to get there money or time back.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I played this at launch and disliked it. The marketing promised total freedom, you can’t do anything close to that. Years later, with expectations properly lowered, I put another 50 hours into it. It’s an ok game for the right audience, but it is not for me.

The open world and atmosphere are strong, but the quests are dull. It feels like a short movie stretched thin to fill a game. Nothing you do in gameplay affects the story. By the end I was a one man army, yet Rogue still told me she had no work because of my “bad reputation” from one failed scripted gig.

The only time the game acknowledges your strength is after the secret ending which, for my full melee build, felt like any other mission: 11 minutes of fighting wrapped in an hour of talking.

In the end, the game looks better than it plays. If you want atmosphere and cutscenes, you might enjoy it, but if you expect meaningful choices, or real player agency, it still falls short.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Payday 3 is a good game, but it removed too much.

They did a lot correct with its stealth system; they majorly overhauled it and made it much more fun to do a mission in stealth, and the Payday team knows this because they request content creators to showcase this when sponsored to play the game.

A major mistake The Payday team made was that they removed too much, especially from the loadout menu. Payday 2 had a much larger variety of weapons, including akimbo (duel-wielded) weapons than Payday three, and the system of buying weapons is through vendors, but the way they organize the weapons is messy and confusing. They also removed a major mechanic from the game, perk decks, which  the lack thereof ruined my enjoyment of the game. Additionally, the Payday team decided to completely remove all melee customization and effectively made melee useless, which I was very disappointed to learn.

Overall, the game is very fun if you want to play a stealth/puzzle game, but as a horde shooter, it massively lets down the player due to the lack of choice in weapons and skills.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ | A game built to last for decades

I’ve been playing Counter-Strike for a very long time — since 2013/2014 on another account — and that alone says a lot about this game. CS has never been about quick changes or hype. Things are often improved only when they really need to be — but when Valve does something, they usually do it right.

Over the years, almost everything has improved:
the graphics, the sound design, the maps, and especially the skins. Counter-Strike feels more modern than ever while still staying true to its core identity.

What also makes CS unique is that it’s more than just a game.
With the skin economy, it’s possible to build a portfolio over time and — with patience and smart decisions — actually earn money. Very few games combine skill, competition, nostalgia, and a real economy like this.

For me, one thing is clear:
Counter-Strike will still be around for many decades to come.
A timeless classic that continues to evolve without losing what made it legendary.

Way better than it was on launch.

I would argue this game's armor system is leagues better than Payday 2, with customizable armor plates and special effects depending on the rig. The guns are great, and the new heists are pretty fun.

"The only thing lacking in this game right now is the skill tree." 

Well, I have good news: they have completely overhauled the skill system. The new cop health/armor system, combined with the armor-piercing skills and armor-breaking skills, makes gameplay fun AND CONSISTENT. You no longer have to micromanage your EDGE and GRIT; now you just get the buffs you spent your hard-earned skill points for. I would finally say the game is in a genuinely good place now. Would highly recommend for only 30$ nowadays.

Review:
completion:
Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition tries to bring a beloved classic into the modern era, but the results are somewhat uneven. The core of San Andreas—its sprawling world, rich story, and addictive gameplay—remains just as engaging and nostalgic as ever. Exploring Los Santos, San Fierro, and Las Venturas with Carl “CJ” Johnson’s journey through gang wars, corruption, and personal redemption is timeless. The Definitive Edition improves on textures, lighting, and character models, aiming to deliver a fresher visual experience. However, these upgrades often fall short of expectations, with inconsistent graphics, awkward animations, and technical hiccups that occasionally disrupt immersion. Controls and user interface improvements inspired by newer Rockstar titles are welcome, making gameplay smoother than the original. While longtime fans might appreciate the nostalgia and newcomers get a chance to experience a GTA classic, the Definitive Edition struggles to fully honor the original’s legacy due to its rough execution. Still, beneath the flaws lies a sprawling and memorable adventure that remains one of the most influential open-world games ever made.

Rating: 7/10

Review:
completion:
Finally done with the battlepass grind for the BF6 cosmetics...

I mean, it's not a completely horrible game. I had more fun on BF2042 than I did with Battlefield 5 and their abhorrent vehicle spam-fest and unlimited sniper nests. At least this entry in the series gives you *some* options to deal with annoyances, albeit they aren't the greatest solutions, especially when they rely on having teammates with half a brain like using my favorite tool, the tracer darts, but it's something at least.

Still, most matches are a sweatfest, just like any other shooter game post-2015ish, but a majority of matches only had a handful of sweat squads while the other 20~25 players are your typical "controller Fortnite Timmy" players, so that's something at least.

Lastly, the removal of the suppression mechanic is simply a completely terrible design decision.

Is it worth full price? God, no. Was I an idiot and didn't read the reviews before buying the completely worthless Elite Edition? Yes I am.

Jesus Christ. The first 5 Minutes have me furiously wanting to scream.

- Guess what's the most pressing issue seems to be at all times, according to the menu highlighting? The Store of uselesness, of course.
- Unskippable Tutorial Cutscene that you're juts thrown into right away.
- Terrible Menu UI with lots of wasted space AND LOADING SCREENS when looking at different classes. I've never, ever seen a game that fumbles so hard on MENU PERFORMANCE.
- Frequent "Hints" windows that break all flow
- Dogshit preamble about (of course) a US-RU centric war in the future. You're part of a righteous rebellion. Gone are the days where realistic scenarios are even alluded to. You're on the right side of this conflict, fuck your grey areas.

Not gonna lie, I really hate everything except the gameplay, which is kind of alright, at the best of times. Which would be fine, like, duh this is a shooter of course the gameplay is what counts... but it's so soulless in its presentation and in-your-face stupidity that it loses all charm. I can't get invested enough to get into the rhythm of this otherwise middling shooter experience.

A clear no from me.

completion: This game does such a phenomenal job at creating such a lived in and immersive world that serves as such an effective backdrop for the story. The Cyberpunk Sci-fi elements, aesthetics and lore are so detailed and well fleshed out. The story is so raw and gut wrenching, often times forcing us to make decisions that are morally grey. From the storytelling to the narrative Cyberpunk 2077 paints a picture of a world not to dissimilar from our own, one ran by corporate greed and corruption. A story where desperate people resort to crime in order to make end meet. A story where often times there are no happy endings. Lots of characters like Johnny Silverhand and V for example are so well written, and have deeply complex personalities and compelling motivations.

Review:
completion: This game was on sale a while back so I bought it because of the positive reviews. I had never played a Dark Souls game before but I like challenging games. I am not going to lie I absolutely HATED this game my first play through. It is open world. No markers on the map telling you where to go. No warning for when you are about to smack a mob above your weight class ( I AM LOOKING AT YOU TREE SENTINEL).  I had to learn how to roll. I had to learn WHEN to roll. It just seemed like I kept getting destroyed no matter where or what I fought. I stopped playing for a number of months and then started playing again. The second time, I FORCED myself to learn how to play it correctly. I accepted that I was going to die but I wanted to start learning from it . Once I did that, the game became incredible. I wasn't afraid to fight things because I could manage it. I did not have to use a summon or ashes of war on every boss. I am able to save runes and can now level up along with my gear. I even learned that just because an enemy is sitting there, does not mean I have to fight it . Make the investment and learn how to play this game. It is so worth it.

Review:
completion:
[h1]Absolute disappointment, and a definitive downgrade from all prior San Andreas versions.[/h1]
Rockstar deserves all the flack for not doing QA (Quality Assurance). I've bought this on sale for GTA 3 initially, then decided I might as well try the other games from this "Definitive Edition".

[b]San Andreas DE is by far the worst version[/b] from the 2 other games in the collection. More bugs, more "features" that seek to either make your gameplay super casual or unpleasant, forced-camera view and control, some cars without wheel animations, getting a wanted level for witnessing a crime committed by a civilian AI, broken weather effects and the list goes on and on . . . for the few QoL (Quality of Life) changes like GPS route and a checkpoint system, there is [b]absolute ZERO REASONS to purchase this.[/b]

Rockstar doesn't need your money if this is the best they can offer, spend the $60 or $30 (if on sale) on something else.

[h3] More of a neutral review [/h3]

Even 3 years after release is this the perfect remaster? Far from it. Lots of removed and changed things, odd design choices, some terrible looking models, bad flight controls, bugs, removed songs, I could go on and on. However, none of it was bad enough for me to stop playing and at heart it still felt like GTA SA I know. Some legitimately good improvements is that you can play with a stable 60 fps without experiencing weird bugs like the OG version and the autosave for missions is great.

OG version is still the GOAT but this version isn't bad either, it's just a bit mediocre.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
2077的灾难时期我没有经历过，我是从2.31开始玩的，玩了几十个小时，除了非常偶尔出现路上的车突然自爆的情况以外好像没见什么影响体验的BUG。

游戏确实很上瘾，很久没有这么上瘾过了，之前令我这么上瘾的还是辐射3、上古卷轴5这种ARPG，地图非常大，任务非常多，我玩的最高难度开局，人物成长比较平滑，技能点还可以随便洗（如果属性点也能洗就更牛逼了）。特别是潜行这块（最高难度不得不玩潜行啊），它设计得就像细胞分裂、耻辱这类潜行游戏一样好，不仅有各种机关、暗道，还得利用黑客技能吸引敌人什么的，真的就得好好思考怎么去破解关卡。最高难度的经验和金钱收益也非常可观，基本上一个任务就可以升一级，快速升级获得技能点，钱又可以去买武器装备，就可以切换成你喜欢玩的别的流派了。

如果说让我不够满意的，就是义体词缀系统，升级才能换词缀，而且词缀搭配那么多，数值范围又那么大，要投入太多的资金和时间进去了。如果说是升级的时候选择要替换的某一个词条，而不是3个全部打乱重新选还差不多，这样升级3次就可以把3个词条全部换掉了。然后再加入一个提升词缀数值的功能，喂相应阶级的材料就能把例如原来的3的近战伤害提升到4，然后逐步提升到7.5满值。另外词缀根据不同的部位应该也有合理的选项，比如表皮和骨骼应该是偏防御的，手臂手掌应该是偏攻击的，腿部应该是偏移动的，不然一个劲地堆攻击，太无脑了

Review:
completion:
The monetisation system in 'Lost Ark' employs tactics that exploit human psychology, encouraging players to continuously spend significant amounts of money to gain an advantage. This system is neither limited to cosmetics nor simply offers additional content through DLCs. Instead, it is integrated into the core game loop of gearing up, persuading players to spend large sums. Moreover, the inclusion of in-game currency conversion is deceptive, obscuring the real-world cost of in-game purchases.

On a positive note, the combat in 'Lost Ark' is nothing short of phenomenal. I thoroughly enjoyed the engaging combat mechanics, the diversity of classes, and the overall design of the game and its maps. However, the game's heavy reliance on exploiting consumer psychology for monetary gain ultimately led me to stop playing. It's disheartening to see a game with such potential undermined by a monetisation strategy focused on extracting every penny from its players.

This game launched as a broken, underwhelming mess, and while the devs have done their best to turn it around, the core design flaws (64v64, specialists, oversized BR-style maps) still drag it down. Vehicles are fun and varied, but the gunplay, attachments, and especially the maps lack depth, the latter being the biggest offender with huge, empty spaces that just feel bad to play on.

Some post-launch maps and updates are decent, and overall the game has become a pretty casual Battlefield experience that can be fun in short bursts. I don’t see it staying alive once BF6 arrives, but revisiting it to unlock the free pass content was a decent time.

Lost Ark – 1,000+ Hours Later
Incredible game held back by bad systems.

Lost Ark has the best ARPG combat and animations I’ve ever seen. The classes are fun, PvE is challenging, and the raids and dungeons are well-designed. The art and character design are top-notch, and the small group content makes connecting with others easier.

But there are two big issues:

Pay-to-win is real. Over time, the game shifted to heavily reward spending money, especially if you want to keep up with guilds or higher-end content.

The grind is brutal. Managing multiple characters daily feels more like a chore than fun, and the constant FOMO wears you down.

I loved this game at launch. But despite all its strengths, I can’t recommend it now. It’s a fantastic ARPG buried under greedy monetization and burnout.

Review:
completion:
This is the first time playing this style of game, and I've seen both the good and bad reviews. I figured I'd give it a shot, but after 10.9 hours of attempt - with two different characters - I'm throwing in the towel.

While it appears there is a plethora of content, the various areas of the game clearly are locked behind high-level bosses who one-/two-shot players. Even within the early area of the game, there are mini-boss characters who absolutely wreck, without the player having a chance apart from staying out of their view. Going into a swampy area and heading toward a small island resulted in a massive dragon that dropped out of the sky and one-shot'd me without so much as a "Good evening, crunchy!"

Apart from the actual play, the menus are not intuitive but instead seem to be an after-thought. Figuring out how things work, where to go to set up primary- and secondary-arrows for bows required looking information up online instead of any tutorial. The learning curve is exceptionally steep while the enjoyment factor is low.

Unfortunately I'll be asking Steam for a refund. One day of playing this was far more than enough for me.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".

- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion: I've played this game since the beta and played for 970 hours, (832 on the EA launcher plus 138 on steam), along with 100% the game. I have watched the devs work and add to the game to make it a decent Battlefield game, they only promised 4 seasons, we got 7 with some mini ones, and a bonus Battlefield celebration season out of nowhere which was super cool, so thank you so much for all of that. Is it different from other Battlefields sure, did it lack a story mode yes (In which is really sad, the lore in the CODEX was super cool, and it's a shame all the lore and the story is reduced to that and seasons.) But at the end of the day, it's still a decent FPS. Movement and gunplay feel great, some maps were good, and the specialists were ok, different yes, but I didn't have a huge issue with them. But if you ask me if I regretted getting a physical PC copy for like $25, and then buying it on Steam for $5, I'll say no, not at all. I really had a great time with 2042, and I'm sure I always will.

I was so ready to hate this game. All the negative reviews made me cautious, but in it's current state, the game is great, I'm honestly having a lot more fun on this than on BF6. The balance feels good, the maps are big, you can play against bots with your friends, and the vehicles aren't made of paper. 

The main points of friction are the operators being cheesy asf, portal feeling kinda tacked on, and frequent FOV glitches. Nothing too bad though, especially considering BF6's current state.

I wouldn't recommend paying full price, but if you can get it on one of it's frequent sales, 100% recommend picking it up.
