A neat multi-purpose game that is not just a Class-based Shooter game (Or it's also called Hero Shooter, I believe?..), but it also works as great Chat Room game. Even if there's quite a few more hero shooters nowadays, they can't achieve the style and communicability of TF2. And even if, other big companies won't go for it anyways, they only wanted the competitive part.
In other words, there probably won't be any kind of game that would somehow replace it, probably not even from indie devs. Maybe I'll be proven otherwise ten years later, but... who knows, who knows...

Review:
completion:
After almost two years since release, there's still barely any content. There are only eight base heists, and most of them aren’t even that good. Some are so short you can finish them in minutes. Others are recycled from previous games with little to no change—so if you played Payday 2, why bother with this one?

About half of the currently existing weapons and heists, which there aren't that many of to begin with, have to be paid for through DLC's. Honestly, they should've just kept adding new content to the game they already had instead of selling back the same content for more money. 

If you were only planning on buying the base game, don't do it, you'll only get about a week of game time in until you get bored. And even if you buy the DLC, you only get four more heists on top of the eight base ones. What you should do instead is buy Payday 2 and don’t look back for another 3–5 years until they've caught up. Or maybe don't. Support developers with less scummy strategies, who actually care about their community instead of viewing them as wallets to steal.

completion:
I'm sorry, I really waited a while to let this game cook and improve. I saw it on sale and thought now is the time to try. This game is not good at all. It feels like it could have been made in Roblox. It feels tacky, the difficulty is incredibly easy no matter what you change it to, the gunplay feels very empty, the maps look so bleak and void of detail, the character voice lines are very half done, the fact that solo mode has only just come out for this game and is still in beta is also very odd to me. the lack of normal missions that are included in the game is minimal, and I personally feel that it is mental that they have already brought out DLC missions. The weapon selection (again without paying for DLC) is abysmal. 

This game has been out for more than long enough to have had the above things ironed out. Payday 2 was always going to be a hard card to trump, but this is not even close at all. it feels rushed, empty of character, and simply a money grab attempt as a follow on from it's predecessor. 

Even at the low price it is currently at, do not buy it. Get Payday 2 for half the price, double the content, and triple the enjoyment.

prompt:

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "ELDEN RING".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I'm not really a fan, but this is my first experience with games from this studio. And while the gameplay overall is fine, everything else leaves a lot to be desired.

I can't say how rich or interesting the story is, because you simply never understand when or why things happen. Your actions do have consequences, which is good, but their logic is completely unclear. In that case, even the most brilliant plot goes down the drain.

The interface is a whole other story: it's such an ancient mess that it feels like the Japanese developer who made it must be 200 years old. You should be glad they managed to come up with anything at all.

As for the music, it's absolutely forgettable. Even now, while playing, I can't recall a single track. The rest of the sound design is decent, though.

The open world is another disappointment. It's not just uninteresting—it’s so oddly designed that you stop caring about it entirely. When everything is hidden behind secret walls, floors, and jars, and that's the only trick the game relies on, smashing walls becomes boring after just a couple of hours. Especially when yet another secret only hides a rune arc or some useless grease.

completion:
The pros: The game play is a massive improvement from the previous installment (which still holds up to this day), it's far smoother, feels more responsive, and movement has been fairly overhauled to give you a lot more mobility. Unfortunately those are the only pros that I have for the game.

Cons: The first negative piece I have about Payday 3 is going to be the server issue. I truly cannot fathom what would make Starbreeze make this an online only game, AND remove the ability to play heists solo. There's a solo mode beta, but it still takes a decent bit of time to load even while using fibre and a high end PC. The weapon variety is also abysmal comparitively when you're not considering DLC weapons. I enjoy the waves rework, but I hate the "Final charge" system. It feels like it's their way of forcing you off the server to free up space for other heisters.

Will add more/tweak review after some more playtime.

completion:
I like it a lot, I don't like the maps as much as Operation Locker on BF4, but I like them a lot more than BF6's maps! 

This game is cool and while its different with its operator / unique skill system, its still at its core a solid battlefield title. Level destrution isn't as noticeable as bf4, but you can still shotgun a hole in a wall of a house and snipe from it if you want. Thats battlefield man. 

This game is cool because you can CALL-IN a vehicle thats ready for spawn right to you using points youve earned from capturing objectives or getting kills, guess what? They drop from the sky like magic right to you in about 2 seconds. DO YOU KNOW WHAT THAT MEANS?!! YOU CAN SPAWN A TANK ON TOP OF A SKYSCRAPER AND USE IT AS A FRICKEN ANTI-TANK ARTILLERY IF YOU WANT

YOU CAN HAVE YOUR FRIEND CALL IN A JET, THEN YOU CALL IN A TANK RIGHT ON TOP OF IT, THEN RIDE THE JET IN THE TANK AND SNIPE OTHER JETS WITH IT!! THATS F***ING SICK!

This game doesnt get much love but it runs great, is interesting, and where it lacks in maps it provides in other ways. Plus, its like always on sale for $5 or less, so, you can't go wrong. 

P.S. They nerfed thermals here, so you can relax a bit

After buying this game about 2 years after release i played this game, i wish i could give a neutral reccomendation but i cant, its a fun game and its not expensive compared to other franchises and what other companies are putting out. I read about the release and it was pretty horrible, the game is in a state now where i would say its a "better graphics, less content" version of payday 2, the gameplay is very similar and i enjoyed playing it for a bit, however if you want a game you can sink hundereds to thousands of hours into having fun: This aint it. I would reccommend getting payday 2 at that point. One big plus i could see for friend groups is that it has crossplay. So you can hiest with your friend that decided to buy a playstation instead of a pc for example. 

Overall TLDLR: 2 years later the game is pretty fun and worth your money but its still very content bare compared to payday 2 (although remember that payday 2 is 12 years old at this point)

Now, in 2025, a couple years after 2.0 came out, the game is even better. I liked it back then, but now it feels like one of the best games of all time, easily on par with Witcher 3. It needed some time in the oven and now it's near perfect. 

I do recommend getting some mods for the character customization, that is this game's primary con for me, there just isn't enough customization options and some of them weirdly lock you to gendered things. Thankfully, there are mods to fix it, but I would still say the vanilla game is near perfect, and the modding scene is well supported by CDPR so it's pretty easy to install everything, even right in the middle of a playthrough. Speaking of playthroughs, im at 200+ hours on my second playthrough now, not including the first 50, and I think i'll finish the game around 300 hours total with everything done and seen (for the most part). I'll still have to do a third playthrough for the last lifepath :3 All this to say, this game is enormous and I love playing in this world

Review:
completion:
Amazing game.
If you like:
-Bladerunner
-Ghost in the shell
-Akira
-Altered Carbon
-Robocop
-Total Recall
-The Matrix
-Deus Ex
-Psycho Pass
Then you'll love this.

If you don't, you'll probably still love this.

Having finished it 4 or 5 times now on other platforms somehow it still never disappoints.
I know many people experienced issues at the outset but in my first 80 hours of playing right after release all that happened was 1 achievement not triggering and 1 crash.
But where the game is now truly shows how much the players are appreciated, so much has been added and adapted since release at no extra cost.
Night city really feels alive. Fanging your car around in the badlands is always fun.
I don't know how they managed to fit so much game into this game and still have every side quest and story feel unique and impactful.
The depth of the storytelling through characters, media, environment and just everything is unparalleled. Whether you just want to skim or dive deep into the details the level of detail they have put into it is phenomenal.
The only thing missing is CyberGwent and gambling.
Extremely excited for what comes next.

I really liked this game. I would say the story can get a bit confusing at parts. I also felt underwhelmed by the main plotline. It wasn't as interesting as I'd hoped. The witcher series had a much more enjoyable and interesting story line. I felt that the games atmosphere, gameplay and graphics is where it really shines. The gameplay is very in depth. You can take fighting to many different areas of expertise. You can be crafty and become a net runner, disabling attackers with net attacks. You can take the exact opposite and be more of a brawler and use melee weapons. The enemy combatants also take many different modes of attack towards you as well. So overall I would recommend the game as it shines in many areas and the part where it didn't shine in the story it made up for in it's other positives.

for short
Positives
+Atmosphere
+Gameplay
+Graphics

Negatives
-Underwhelming main plot

Review:
completion:
I have not had this much fun exploring in a game in a long time. And the fact that it's just a tad easier than other Souls games in terms of enemies and the generousity of checkpoints (bonfires, site of grace etc) just makes a bit less frustrating when dying. I feel like this game can be played many times over without getting bored. 
It is however giving me seconds-long lag spikes every now and then, which I dont know where it comes from, whether it's poorly optimization for PC or something running in the background that sets it off. And the game keeps running while the spike happens (not like freeze/lag if GPU was throttling or something, seems more like packet loss spike) so it kind of catches up after a sec or two, so I dont think it's hardware related (1440p, 5700x3d, 32GB ram, rtx 3080). It's getting annoying and i've seen that this is a known issue, I just assumed they would have fixed it after 3-4 years.
But other than that, really awesome game.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Payday 3 was always going to struggle to steal the show with its predecessor boasting a decade of support but this was a particularly fantastic blunder. Recent updates show a hint of promise but the fundamental issue of the games reliance on servers buggered up its launch and spells certain doom for its future. 

Why am I searching for servers for my private lobby? Why does my game need to process painting a mask or buying a gun? Why am I being ushered through the pre-game setup, as if I have to get on with it and make room for the next group of heisters? Why am I lagging in my own sodding server? Leave me alone.

It's not a terrible foundation, really. But it will need time and effort to reach the level of content and depth of its systems Payday 2 has, the only question is: how many of us are willing to risk investing in this game until that point? After feeling robbed myself here, I don't think I am.

Title: Battlefield 2042 - The Future of Disappointment

Review:
Do you like paying full price for a tech demo? Do you dream of weapons that sound like Nerf guns, maps the size of small countries but with the action density of a retirement home, and “specialists” who all look like Fortnite interns on casual Friday, 128 players running marathons across empty maps, guns that sound like airsoft toys, Then boy, do I have a product for you.

This game promised “the future of Battlefield” and delivered… a futuristic PowerPoint presentation where bullets are optional, and patch notes are the real endgame.

Pros:

- The uninstall button works flawlessly.
- Pretty clouds.

Cons:

- Everything under them.

Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
-Fun game to play but there are some complex mechanics to be learn (like building characters and playing efficiently), you need (most of the time) 3rd party sources to learn them. 

-Combat is ultra fun and raids are amazing (Helpful tip : If you don't like challenging bosses and mechanics, pick an easier class to do them). Like in any other mmo game, better dps means less stressful time and it's not easy to deal good damage with every class.

Also, there are a lot of progression involved, if you pay lots of money you can skip most of them, or you need to grind f2p for months. But if you stop trying to speedrun and be the strongest (in a known p2w game), you can just play casually with less characters and less hours a day, there are a lot of horizontal content with good rewards and you can make gold from simple things like gathering or weeklies. Why you should bother with a p2w game ? Because it has some of the best content to play in rpg's. Of course, not a game for everyone.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Lost Ark".
Target rating: 3/10.

- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers

Review:
completion:
This is a personal thumbs down from me, though some other people might not mind the things that I disliked the most about the game.  But hey, its a free game, so why not give it a try?

This game has an interesting story and an amazing character creator.  It's a shame that you never get to really see your character (or any one else's) because of the top-down isometric view point of the game.  You can mostly see the top of their head and they are small and feel far away.  I don't feel very immersed when i can't even see the combat animations properly.

The Korean VO pack was a nice DLC for free.  The English VO sounded very stilted and unnatural.  Still, that's only a minor flaw to me.  I could even tolerate the point and click movement style, even though it's not what i'd prefer.

The art style and concept of the game reminds me a lot of Black Desert or Blade and Soul, in the way that you destroy masses of enemies at once which can be fun and satisfying.  There is an attempt at lifeskilling but it's not very deeply developed.  The view and lack of feeling immersed just broke it for me.  It really Just made me want to go play Black Desert instead.

They do not allow you to just grind, because they set daily/weekly limits on every bit of gameplay. Which also makes matchmaking for endgame content a pain because unless you're in a guild and shelve out real cash to keep up with your guildmates, you're not going to have fun trying to find groups. If you can afford to blow a couple thousand dollars/euros, then this game could be really fun for you, if not then just look for something else.

completion:
When it released this port was an absolute disaster but now after the patches it's a real good time.  I had 0 crashes, maybe 3 random short stutters and very few noticeable bugs or glitches in my 50 hours.

GTA 3 is a solid foundation that has aged horribly, Vice City massively improves the formula then San Andreas again further improves almost everything and is a genuine masterpiece.  There's a reason many people call it the best game on the PS2.

My only complains are probably that the Radio OST is noticeably weaker than in VC and the gang warfare mechanic gets real old real fast.  Those are minor complaints though, SA is bloody brilliant and everyone should play it at least once.

Review:
completion:
This game is...
well its good?
Following a rocky start this game has slowly crawled it ways back into light, but the issue with that being that the game now, is finally in the state it should have been released in. While the heists are fun and new, the amount of them pales in comparison to the previous game. Speaking of, comparing Payday 3 to Payday 2 is night and day. Both games have their advantages, Payday 2 is a lot more goofy and comedic with its weaponry and how the overall game acts, while Payday 3 takes a lot more of a realistic approach, which does actually work for it. The guns are fun and the perk system is fun and interesting to mess around with, but another issue is the paid content. For a game approaching 2 years old, a good chunk of the weaponry and the heists are locked behind DLC, which would be okay, if not for the fact the base game is $45! I really want this game to do well, as everything about it is fun, if not for the fact you have to pay an arm and a leg to play it. Please Starbreeze, give the game a medic bag and help it get out of custody.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Team Deathmatch stands out as one of the most enjoyable modes in Battlefield 2042 because it keeps the action focused and intense. The smaller-scale combat helps mask the game’s biggest weakness, which is its large, often poorly designed maps.

Unfortunately, the squad-based system limits coordination in larger public matches. With squads capped at four players, organizing as a single, cohesive team is nearly impossible. This restriction takes away the large-scale teamwork that Battlefield has always been known for.

As a group of ten friends, we can’t all join the same match like we could in past Battlefield titles. Unless we use custom Portal servers, we’re forced to split up, which really hurts the experience. Sadly, it seems this design direction may continue into Battlefield 6, which is disappointing for fans who miss the franchise’s classic large-squad coordination.

Battlefield 2042 can still be fun in the right mode, but its restrictive squad system make it feel like a missed opportunity for the series.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
One of the best GTA games in the franchise. This game is packed with so much to do and truly paved teh way for what the devs will release in the future. They fixed alot of the problems from the initial release, but there are still a few bugs, nothing game breaking, that make you roll your eyes. Some texture pop in, animations and sounds not playing properly etc. 
There are a few frustrating aspects still present, such as AI driving the wrong way, or appearing out of no where on the highway going full speed at you. Random objects that have insane collision on them, noticed this alot on the races, such as San Fierro Hills, where the road posts, are moveable, but if you hit them, you may, or may not, go flying into the water.
Or maybe the more funny ones, if you push an AI off their track in a chase or race, they will do whatever they can to get back to the point they were at. Such as the main mission, where you chase Pulaski in the desert, I pushed him off the cliff edge to the road below and then followed after him. He then drove straight up a vertical cliff to where I had pushed him off.

....But it is definitely playable all the way through.

Review:
completion:
Objectively, GTA SA Remastered is a very good title. You can still feel its age due to some of the mechanics and visuals reminding you it originally came out in 2004, BUT the remaster? It does a decent job cleaning things up for modern systems. I never actually finished or played San Andreas properly back in the day, just messed around on friends’ PCs, but now diving into it properly, it’s easy to see why it was such a big deal.

There’s an insane amount to do. That's a huge plus. The story isn't on the level of GTA IV’s which is more grounded, an emotional narrative, but it’s fun and packed with personality. You can also clearly see how many ideas from GTA V were born here.

For a game from 2004, it’s massive. The remaster helps make it more approachable today, and despite its rough edges, it’s still a blast to play. 

Currently working on the 100%.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".

Guidelines:

- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
A wonderful game that gave me a lot of positive emotions while playing. The plot draws you in more and more with each dialogue, and by the end of the game, you feel like you are living the experiences of your character. The main characters around whom the main story revolves are well thought out, each with a wonderful story and a wonderful ending to their story.
One of the game's strengths is its graphics. The graphics in this game are very beautiful and are the perfect complement to the cyberpunk world. You are fully immersed in the game world.
Unfortunately, the game has a small flaw. There are bugs, and while playing through the game several times, I encountered NPCs who behaved inappropriately while driving vehicles. The most annoying bug is that at certain points in the game, I fell through the map, and to get out, you have to completely restart the game.
(I also played the DLC for this game, which has an incredibly touching story with an unexpected ending. I recommend everyone buy the game together with the DLC!)

completion: They fixed most of the issues the game had at launch. There's a solo mode now (although it's much more demanding on your computer) and most of the heists are at least somewhat fun. Dare I say, Boys in Blue is pretty damn good. Alot of the voice acting is amazing as well, with the pager/radio response lines taking the cake as some of the funniest. Chains calling himself a werewolf gave me a good chuckle when I was playing the tutorial, and Clover calling Dallas captain america will always be funny. The game is a little lacking with free content, and there's a lot of power creep with the desert eagle effectively making most other sidearms useless, but otherwise the content and weapon drought isn't too bad, especially considering you can join other people who have the DLC heists, just like in Payday 2. I'd say it's not worth 30 bucks right now, but pick it up when it's on sale.

This game's reputation is, unfortunately, a stain that no review will be able to wash away. Yes, you've heard right - you can spend endlessly in pursuit of power. Grouping is difficult, because power is the prerequisite for acceptance by other players. The game's raids are brutally difficult, further exacerbating the need for power.

That's only part of the story, though. Lost Ark is a brilliant game with the most engaging combat and character progression that I've ever experienced in an MMORPG. It is brutal, unforgiving, yet highly rewarding once you've mastered its systems. I cannot recommend it enough.

After 414 hours, I can confidently say:
I still miss easy shots and blame lag.

Pros:
- Classic Counter-Strike gameplay that never gets old
- New smoke effects are so good I sometimes forget where I am
- Every round feels like “this time I’ll rank up”

Cons:
- My aim did not improve with 414 hours
- Teammates still rush B without a plan
- One last match always turns into five more

Overall:
If a game can keep me playing for 414 hours,
it’s clearly doing something right.
Counter-Strike 2 looks better, feels familiar,
and still ruins my sleep schedule.
Recommended.

completion:
G.I. Joe-ass video game. I picked it up for way cheap in 2025 and had some fun with it. I kinda dig the near-future tone of the game. Gunplay feels kinda awkward like Battlefield V. Some good maps, but also some maps that just feel barren and unfinished. The hero system is just a strange decision, but once I'm in the game, I don't really notice it. I would've preferred just letting the player change their character freely like in every other modern game in this series. 

Portal is confusing and not as good as just having user servers. Also, the Portal search functionality, for whatever reason, is very finicky. I don't know, if I wanted to play these older Battlefield games, I'd just go boot them up with some fan mods, and not try to play some bastardized version of them through 2042.

I've had the game crash on me at least 4 times in 12 hours of play. I might return to this in the future for the specific look and feel of 2042, but there are better Battlefield games - hell, there are OTHER Battlefield games.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Lost Ark".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Fun game if you played since launch. Great combat. But I can't in good faith recommend starting to play it.

Worst new player experience in existence. Due to weekly lockouts, you will spend months soloing content nobody runs anymore before catching up to current endgame, where you will be gatekept - because game strongly encourages running 3 raids per week on 6 chars, people want fast clears and won't risk taking someone inexperienced as they really want their 18 weekly raids to take 30 minutes each rather than 3 hours each. If you endure, after a few months you can catch up, somewhat. You can also swipe to skip the grind, but being gatekept for no experience will still apply.

Game is pay to win in the sense that it enables cash to in-game currency exchange. There's technically no advantage over other players that can be obtained exclusively by swiping, but paying enough can skip literal years of grinding, making you relatively stronger than players who spent less.

In short, game with amazing combat, great story - but badly translated and with mixed quality of voice acting, awful progression and equally bad, actively hostile new player experience.

completion: If I could give this a mixed I would. The bones of this game are great, better than PD2 I'd say. The mechanics, feel, and everything else are all there.  After the armor update the game is genuinely enjoyable to play a few rounds in. What's not great is the lack of content and the obvious abandonment from the devs, they've confirmed only a skeleton crew is working on the game now; the latest heist was made by 2 (two!) people. I genuinely believe this game has so much potential, moreso than PD2 had, but they just, gave up. Threw in the towel after a bad reception and low player count despite there being so much good to build upon. This game will likely stop receiving new content after this year, when their next game releases. 100% worth to grab on sale, but full price? Definitely not. RIP Payday.

Review:
completion:
player who fell headfirst into this neon dystopia, Cyberpunk 2077 has become my digital home.
Storytelling That Feels Real‌
The moment I saw Johnny Silverhand’s ghost flicker in my vision, I knew this was no ordinary RPG. V’s struggle against the Relic chip isn’t just about survival—it’s a soul-shaking battle between humanity and technology. Side quests like "Never Fade Away" made me laugh, cry, and question what it means to be "alive."
Customization That Defines Me‌
Choosing the Street Kid lifepath shaped V’s grit, while my cyberware upgrades turned me into a walking experiment. Want to be a silent hacker or a bullet-spraying beast? The game lets you live out every cyberpunk fantasy.
World That Breathes‌
Night City isn’t a backdrop—it’s a character. Corporate ads taunt me in the rain, NPCs share secrets in back alleys, and every district pulses with its own rhythm. Here, I’m not just a player—I’m a citizen of a world that feels alive.
Verdict: A Cyberpunk Masterpiece‌
Despite its flaws, Cyberpunk 2077 is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. If you love stories that stay with you long after the credits roll, this is your game.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
With 700+ hours played over five years — since launch on GOG — I can confidently say I’ve seen Cyberpunk 2077 at its worst and at its absolute best.
From a rough, buggy release, it rose like a phoenix into a visually breathtaking, deeply immersive masterpiece.
The story is mature, emotional, and gripping, with exceptionally well-written characters.
Playing as female V completely won me over — Cherami Leigh’s brilliant voice acting adds real depth and humanity.
Johnny Silverhand (portrayed by Keanu Reeves) is charismatic, abrasive, and surprisingly layered.
And Judy… beautifully written, emotionally grounded, and unforgettable.
These characters don’t just exist in the story; they stay with you.
Combat and progression are flexible and rewarding, even for someone who isn’t really into FPS games.
High replayability, meaningful choices, and multiple endings make every playthrough worthwhile.
Thanks to modders, the game has become even richer and more customizable.
I’ve tried and used many mods long-term — not as gimmicks, but because they genuinely improved the experience.
Over the years, Cyberpunk 2077 didn’t just recover — it evolved into something truly remarkable.

Thank you, Lost Ark.

"Would not recommend."

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:

- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
After being able to replay the game and truly appreciate the atmosphere my opinion on Cyberpunk still hasn't changed much. While it is incredibly versatile, incredibly buggy and visually stunning it still in my eyes remains as a pretty cookie cutter 'Action-RPG' with nothing too interesting to boot. 

An very vast and in-depth character creator and customization system...for a 95% first-person experience. Most you will see of your character besides during driving is with the shadows which are less than stellar.

The story branching into these multiple paths with your choices impacting the ending is not played smoothly. This isn't even to boot how the romantic options in the game are both limited and very stupid from a story perspective.

None of the games systems were explained well enough for me to take full advantage of them during the course of my gameplay.

Overall Cyberpunk remains very fun and incredibly easy to access but I would not and never lord it as an incredible game. It was a bug-filled mess on launch and still wears those scars. It's still good in a pinch however, just incredibly middle of the road.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".

- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Despite all of the fixes, map changes, balance passes and "immersion" updates, 2042 is not only the worst battlefield game, but probably one of the most tone deaf shooters I have ever played.

Wide open maps with no cover or destruction.
A specialist system that nobody asked for, and was crammed in to fit a class system that is still horrible with obvious best in slot picks.
Weapon balancing that makes Hardline go weak at the knees.
Lore that might as well be from another game that is much better than this shit.
Worst of all, probably one of the most gut-wrenching renditions of the Battlefield theme, along with it's own exquisite selection of wet farts for music.

Just because this game goes on sale for 3-4 dollars does not excuse all of it's issues; you can buy Battlefield 1, 5, 4, and 3 for the same prices on their sales. Hell, you can even buy Bad Company 2 and play online with community servers.

The only legitimate reason to buy this game is if you [b]really[/b] don't have any other shooters to play, or you like burning money on whatever.

Even if Battlefield 6 is a disaster, there is genuinely no conceivable way it could be worse than 2042.

Battlefield veteran here. I’ve been playing since Battlefield 2, and I’ve played all of them  except for Battlefield 5. I skipped that one because I didn’t like the beta and wasn’t going to pay for a game I knew I wouldn’t play.

But this one, Battlefield 2042, honestly… I played the beta, and it was terrible. I played for a month of EA’s subscription just to try it, and when the trial ended, I didn’t renew it because it simply wasn’t worth it. The game was incomplete at launch, the maps were bad, and there’s really not much to praise about it.

Some people might like it, but as someone who’s played all the Battlefield games, there’s nothing here that stands out in a good way. I’ve got around 250 hours in it only because I bought it on sale for about 4 bucks, and I was grinding BF6 skins in Portal servers while AFK. That’s the truth.

Don’t waste your time buying or playing this game. There are better ways to spend your time. If you want to play Battlefield, my opinion and just my opinion play Battlefield 6 or 4, or 3, or even Battlefield 1 if you like World War I settings. But this one, Battlefield 2042, really isn’t worth it.

Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game — it’s a mental space. Night City doesn’t exist… but it acts like it does. It breathes, it watches you, and most of the time it straight-up doesn’t care about you. And that’s exactly why it pulls you in.

The visuals are insane. Neon bleeding into the rain, ads screaming in your face, skyscrapers making you feel small as hell. Everything is loud, dirty, hyper-tech and decayed at the same time. It’s the future — but a broken one. And somehow, that ugliness is beautiful.

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion: Battlefield 2042 had been in my library for a while, but I had never got around to play it until after the Battlefield 6 Open Beta. At First I didn't really enjoy it, maybe because it was so different from what I'd been used to, or maybe because I wasn't good. But once I continued to get a couple more hours in I started to like it. The gun play is smooth and fast, while also managing to feel semi realistic (unlike cod). If I had unlimited storage I would definitely continue to play even though I already own Battlefield 6. Even if Battlefield 6 is better game in almost every way, Battlefield 2042 is still a great game and an even better, cheap alternative.

prompt:
You are a regular Steam user.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Battlefield 2042 didn’t just have a bad launch — it feels like a game that never really understood what made Battlefield work in the first place.

Yes, the launch was rough: bugs, missing features, poor performance. Some of that was patched later. But even now, the core problems are still there. The maps are too large and empty, matches feel chaotic instead of tactical, and teamwork matters far less than it used to.

The Specialist system is a big part of the problem. It removes clear class roles and turns Battlefield into something closer to a hero shooter, which just doesn’t fit this franchise. Instead of improving the formula, it waters it down.

Post-launch support also feels late and reactive. Major fixes only arrived after a large part of the player base had already left, which makes it hard to trust the game as a long-term multiplayer experience.

Battlefield 2042 may be more stable now than at launch, but “more stable” doesn’t mean “good.” It still doesn’t deliver the Battlefield experience many players expected.

Do not buy this at full price. Even at a discount, know what you’re getting into. This feels less like a failed patch cycle and more like a failed direction.

I bought this when it came out but struggled to get into it, holidays this year roll around, what should I play?
I know I'll try Elden ring again, it's been awhile. Start the download thinking this is going to look fantastic on the new 32 inch curved OLED I have now instead of the old 24 inch I last played it on. 
I start the game and everthing looks pretty bad, okay some tweaks to the settings usually works.
So I go into display settings to find it's running in 2560x1440 when it should be 3440x1440.
After setting it to that what do we have now?....Giant black bars at the side of the screen.
I figure there's no way in hell a game like this doesn't support 32 inch monitors properly, but alas after some googling that is in fact the case.
And while I know this dosen't really warrant a negative review and is just a bit of whinging, "the squeaky wheel gets the grease" and all that.
Plus, I mean come on, what the hell?
Mongo is appalled.

Cyberpunk is honestly on another level. In many ways it feels more advanced than GTA V and even Red Dead Redemption, The driving alone deserves respect so the steering feels so real it makes other games feel like toy cars. people complain about no third person view but they can't see that  this game is clearly built for first person. prompt:
You are a regular Steam user.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
The game is amazing, very immersive, and takes creative risks which I appreciate in a game. The netrunner game mechanics are super fun, and the story is compelling, making you attached to characters and invested in the outcomes. 

At times, the game almost becomes a movie, with interactive cutscenes that last 15 minutes. Again, I personally like this aspect as it allows the creators to progress the narrative in a compelling way..

A few downsides:

I wish there were more explorable interiors, dialog options with random NPCs (outside of quests), and I wish there were not so many plotpoints. 

This is the type of game you have to play 2 or 3 times to fully understand wtf is happening. You are frequently thrusted into the middle of some situation where it's difficult to understand your characters motivation for being involved, or the NPCs motivation for their actions. There are too many random side plot points that are hard to understand 

The game is pretty dark which some people might not like, but I personally didn't mind it

Overall, I would give this gamed an 8/10

completion:
GTA San Andreas - A Timeless Nostalgia

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas isn't just a game; it's a gateaway to my childhood - a vivid memory of simpler times. From the moment CJ uttered, "Ah ....., here we go again," I was pulled into a world that felt boundless, where Grove Street wasn't just a place, but home.

Those late nights spent sneaking in one more mission, cruising through Los Santos with 2Pac on the radio - it wasn't just gaming; it was pure magic. I didn't just play the story; I was lived it, customizing cars, exploring deserts, and embracing the chaos that made it all unforgettable.

San Andreas is more than a masterpiece; it's a time capsule of laughter, freedom, and innocence. It reminds me of the GOLDEN DAYS when my heart - a timeless reminder of the joy of being young and free.

Still grateful for those memories, and always will be.

A forever-grateful player❤️

Review:
completion: Basically, the game is really fun. The story is cool, the skills are flashy, there's lots of side content, and the dungeons are challenging. But here's the problem. After 400 hours, I've played 95% of the game alone. There are virtually no players in T3, and it's designed so that you can play it alone because the developers know that you're completely on your own. I thought it would be better in T4 because it's “presumably” end-game content. Even there, I can't find any people, and if there is a party, you have to wait forever. I only see parties for end-end-game content, but until then, it's NOT an MMORPG just because you see some people in towns. And now comes the worst part: from T4 onwards, you realize that progress becomes difficult without the cash shop. I have nothing against progress becoming more difficult, but I haven't found a way to grind. All you can do are dailies and weeklies. And if you have to spend $500+ a month to get “the experience,” then it ultimately leads to Lost Ark being a mobile MMORPG light.

It's been nearly 3 year since my purchase.
Amazon and Smilegate did a horrible job and continues to bring this title to the west; they continue to either use basic non-MMO marketing logic or ignorance to the west depending on which company you look at.

The game was fun, when 1 million people were around. 
It is not fun when the 9 others I started with have quit.
This game is designed to be played with 7 other people - 20 hours+ a week. In unison. 
You must also be willing to spend either an extra 40 hours a week to grind materials or drop 25-100 dollars a week on this game to meet upgrade requirements.

As of this review, if you intend to play and are a 100% completionist - stop. You will be missing multiple wallpapers, 1-time-event things etc ... unless they drop some FRESH servers with the old Tier 1-2-3 system, you'll never get those achievements.

If you are SOLO, you will not enjoy this game.

You've been warned.

prompt:

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Fun game.

Well worth a buy on sale if you like tinkering with game modes.
I like the Portal experience where i can make my own game and rules.
Like WW2 US soldiers versus Modern RU for example.
Another cool feature is projectile speed that can be changed ,so a bullet flys at half speed.
I also like to tweak soldier health and vehicle health too.
I think the default vehicle health is too high -
realistically a couple of Rpgs should take out a vehicle - so I reduce this health value.
You can make the game 2 shot kills if you want for infantry ,maybe 1 for snipers and shotgun slugs.


Runs OK on older laptop -just limit fps to 57fps and play at 720p ,this will reduce CPU heat a lot. In a similar vein i made a User.cfg to use only 2/3rds of my cpu cores and threads -this also reduces CPU heat.
The only problem I think without doing these 2 things is the high CPU heat when playing game.
The GPU does not seem to overheat at all.
If managed then the game is great.

Definitely one of the most fun MMO's ive played, if not the most fun for PvE. I did love the PvP but queues were a bit long and raids take priority.
The raids imo are incredibly fun when compared to other MMO's like wow, Valtan (first Legion raid) is an incredible experience. 
The reason why I would not recommend to new players is that its an RNG based game that unless you play at least 6 high item lvl characters, you struggle to hit content on release then only get gatekept after that. 
I still experience gatekeeping daily on my alts, people want 1520+ item lvl for a 1460 raid etc.
If you have friends or want to experience the early raids - the free powerpass you get to make your character is definitely worth it... the only issue is finding learning parties, ive enjoyed running a lot of learning parties but its rare to see anyone trying to help.

the game is nothing but RNG with more and more layers of RNG.

But I do have issues with where the game's direction is going, and of course, the future of it.
1 year with no DLC and no communication despite being a 'live-service', and I saw people thought the advent calendar final reveal was a letdown. It's REALLY worrying.

Would I recommend this? yeah sure, buy it during discount seasons.
Would I keep playing this? probably... Not, until they announced something. 

For now go get Payday 2 (or The Heist) if you're unsure if you want to get this game or not.

V1 13hrs. Bought this on release and couldn't even play because of severe stuttering no matter the settings. Refunded and bought on sale later. They actually put in a lot of work to fix this one. +Gun play. The gunplay feels more like the far older battlefields except smoother. its actually more reliable and consistent. Your weapons don't feel quite so unpredictable like they do in the other more recent titles.

-New Maps. The new maps are mostly terrible. Way to big and empty. They look nice, but play like garbage.
-Vehicles. The vehicles are far to annoying in this title. There are way too many and the over sized maps grant them complete dominance.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
If you have never played the original GTA SA, this game is a fantastic recreation of the old game. It has its bugs here and there, but the story still holds up to modern times (2025), and the upgraded graphics and control scheme really help make the game remain playable.
Not to mention that some of the bugs can actually enhance the game slightly (such as the burglary money glitch)

The game engine is a bit buggy; the Rockstar engine can't handle above 147 fps, but I have experienced that with this game, above 138 fps creates graphical issues, and above 60 fps creates animation timing issues (cars moving to the wrong location when being driven by NPCs and the like). 

This game plays quite nicely at 30 fps if you have a controller, so if you want the best experience, locking the game to 30 and playing with a controller will have the best playing result. 

On a Radeon GPU, I would advise disabling all GPU enhancement features for the game since most of them conflict with the game engine, such as Enhanced VSync or Anti-Lag, which creates this really bad tearing effect in the game that is very distracting. Not sure if this is also the case on Nvidia GPUs.

Review:
completion: Cyberpunk 2077 is one of the most dynamic games I've ever played. I've played it through fully twice, and each time my experience was different, as was my V. The way I interacted with characters, and the things I chose to do largely hinging on how I felt at the time. And players can do exactly that, choose what they want to do, whether it be to help or to fight the cops, to go in guns blazing or to use stealth, to make friends with characters, or ditch them. The game provides such a sense of freedom while still following a guided set of actions that lead to Cyberpunk's many endings. I'll focus specifically on my first run because it was the one I went into without any prior knowledge of the game. Overall, it was a run filled with options made because of opportunities not taken. Some because they never realized the options were there, and some because they didn't realize it was a better choice until it was too late. All of which is extremely human. It's one of the reasons I like this game. It's human. If you're someone who is really into games that match that description, "Human", then I'd bet Cyberpunk 2077 is for you.

⭐ 5/5 – Would Get Jump‑Attacked by a Bush Again ⭐
Elden Ring is the only game where I can confidently say I was emotionally supported by a jellyfish and emotionally destroyed by a goat. I set out to become the Elden Lord; instead, I became a full‑time employee of the “You Died” screen.
The open world is gorgeous—so gorgeous that I kept stopping to admire the scenery, which is exactly when a random bird the size of a Honda Civic decided to end my career. Every NPC speaks in riddles, and I’m 90% sure half of them are gaslighting me. I met a guy with a pot for a head and trusted him more than any human in my real life.
Combat is incredible. By “incredible,” I mean I spent three hours fighting a boss who has more phases than the moon. When I finally won, I felt like I had personally ended a generational curse.
10/10. A masterpiece. I have no idea what’s going on, but I’m having a great time.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Cyberpunk 2077 é um jogaço. Peguei pra jogar sem muita expectativa e acabei me viciando fácil. Night City é simplesmente absurda de tão bonita e cheia de detalhes, dá vontade de sair andando sem fazer missão nenhuma só pra explorar. A ambientação cyberpunk é muito bem feita, tudo tem personalidade, desde os becos até os prédios gigantes cheios de neon

A história me prendeu demais. As missões principais são muito boas e as secundárias surpreendem, várias parecem até missão principal de tão bem escritas. Os personagens são marcantes, principalmente o Johnny Silverhand, que acaba virando uma presença constante e bem interessante durante o jogo.

O gameplay é bem livre. Dá pra jogar no stealth, sair hackeando tudo, ou meter o louco no tiroteio. Conforme você vai upando e colocando implantes, o personagem fica cada vez mais forte e divertido de jogar. A sensação de progressão é muito boa.

Hoje dá pra dizer que Cyberpunk 2077 finalmente virou o jogo que prometeram. Recomendo demais pra quem curte mundo aberto e uma história bem feita.

prompt:

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "Lost Ark".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion: I kept hearing about the amazing endgame and how much content there was, but the farther along I got the more I realized that entire "game" is just a thinly veiled marketing vector that throws a shit ton of stamina or time-gated systems at you to annoy you into spending money to get past them or make some grinds more rewarding. There's a huge difference between a game designed to be fun, and a game designed to be engaging, and I feel like a lot of people struggle to understand that. Lost Ark's business strategy is literally create a problem to sell a solution. I'm convinced everyone who still plays it just has Stockholm syndrome, because that's what it felt like to me in hindsight. Once I finally got off for longer than a week, the only feelings I could ascribe to the whole experience was a sensation akin to finding out someone I'd been hanging out with was only around to get me to buy things for them.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 3/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
What they did with PAYDAY 3 is the same as what happened to CS2 – a brand new fake for fans of meaningless PvE FPS games.

I’ve played PAYDAY 2 for more than 600 hours and I still want to play it more and more, even after years of pause. But I can’t stand PAYDAY 3 for even 2 hours – it sucks a lot.

This isn’t a full game even after almost 2 years since release. It’s very raw. If it was just a demo, maybe it could be good.

It’s not PAYDAY anymore, it’s just another meaningless FPS copy-pasted from others. They even stole coins from the John Wick universe.

Ok, now we have drones, overkill weapons, and many new forces, BUT:

NO heist planning
NO justified mechanics
NO sense of heists
NO story
NO safehouse

ONLY 20 achievements.

And thank God, a BETA single-player mode to play with bots!

prompt:
You are a regular Steam user.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Counter-Strike 2".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
CS2 is the only game that can ruin my mood, test my patience, and still be the first thing I boot up every day. Same Counter-Strike, new engine, same pain. And somehow… it’s still amazing.

Gunplay is clean, smokes are actually insane now, and when you hit a perfect one-tap you feel like the best player to ever touch a mouse. Five seconds later you whiff an entire mag and start blaming ping, teammates, and life in general.

Matchmaking is a social experiment. One teammate thinks it’s Faceit, one is playing with music on, and one just discovered WASD. But when the team clicks? Pure cinema. Clutches still make your heart stop, comebacks feel illegal, and winning a close game hits harder than it should.

Is it balanced? Sometimes. Is it stressful? Always. Do I still queue again instantly? Obviously.

Pros:
✔ Gunplay still unmatched
✔ Smokes go crazy
✔ Nothing feels better than a clutch

Cons:
✘ Teammates (again)
✘ Mental health debuff

Final Verdict:
CS2 is toxic, stressful, and somehow perfect. If you love competitive pain, ego checks, and yelling “BRO HE’S ONE HP,” welcome home.

In its current state, I cannot recommend Team Fortress 2. To anyone.

I love this game, I've loved this game since I started playing it, but the only real way to play it now is to join the very limited amount of community servers with specific rulesets that aren't the vanilla game or don't run the standard maps in rotation.

Valve has left the game in a borderline unplayable state since Meet Your Match released and have done little to nothing to fix it. Casual mode (and by extension Competitive mode) are horribly buggy messes that should have never been introduced into the game. A matchmaking system is entirely antithetical to what Team Fortress 2 is; a casual pick-up put-down first person shooter. Until this issue is addressed, my review will remain negative.

#YouWillNotPlay

This game is amazing. It blows all other moba's out of the water. You can play anyone you want, you can play tons of mods. The only issue in this entire game is learning. The tutorial is impossible. If you can't find someone to teach you, you aren't going to learn. It is that hard. The other problem is the community. I love them, but I have heard them doing some awful things. So if you are going into the game cold, do three things.
-Demo Heros before you play
      This game is hard enough, but some heroes are near impossible to start on. I reccomend heroes with simple spells and straightforward passives. Pick faceless void or sniper. Both very easy...
-Practice with bots
    Practice or the community will hate you, also... expiriment. There are many secrets hidden in the settings you can try.
-Report players who are abusive in language or tell you to quit or uninstall. They probably feed as much as you do.
      This is the only way to better the community

BF2042: The Underrated Titan of the Battlefield Franchise

Honestly, BF2042 has evolved into something special — F2042 delivers some of the best core gameplay the series has ever seen.
Best movement, best weapon handling, best vehicle handling, great spotting, and great maps — alone, those five points make it a dream to play for anyone who values the classic Battlefield feeling refined to perfection.

Add to that better weapon customization and modification, maps spanning nearly every Battlefield era, vault weapons and vehicles, and the freedom to jump into ANY (classic) gamemode — all while enjoying constant events, a ton of easter eggs, and hidden secrets scattered throughout. It’s the most content-rich and flexible Battlefield to date.

Most importantly, it’s now a complete, fully functional, non-buggy, premium FPS — and you can grab it for just a couple of bucks. That’s insane value for what you’re getting.

After experiencing how polished and satisfying BF2042 has become, it’ll be a long while before I feel like dishing out cash for an overpriced, monetized BF6.
BF2042 has earned its redemption and is high value giggles

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
It's honestly solid. It did not have a smooth launch, as I recall it myself (we bought the game, trailers looked great, nobody knew the terrible condition). 

That being said, they have turned it around. It runs decent, feels as good as the old pc ports with quality of life improvements, and looks really nice. The unreal engine was not a bad choice here.

Art style and character models were not the right direction and that's my main criticism. Some areas look like an unreal engine tech demo and not in line with the original 3D era GTA games.

Other than that, these are pretty much exactly what I was looking for. I like the simple fun of the classics a lot more sometimes, and these get pretty much everything down. Any missing content you need, just mod it back in. Otherwise I'm happy with it.

Don't get it for base price. Only get it on sale.

Review:
completion:
From the point of view of a more casual RPG player. I did not necessarily like Elden Ring in the beginning, in fact, I returned it the first time I bought it. But over time, I was able to appreciate the deep lore, game content, diversity of builds, and pure creativeness that is in the players hand for how they want to play the game. Initially that can feel daunting, especially with many large AAA titles quite literally spoon feeding you content on a monorail around a theme park. 

Elden Ring does quite the opposite. It will feel overly punishing in the beginning, but turn into a fruitful experience in the end appreciating a game that is complete upon release but lets you find out what it has to offer, and beat it how you want to beat it

I actually avoided this game for a long time because of its bad early reputation, but I finally decided to give it a go — and I’m really glad I did.

I went all in on it — 100% achievements, all endings, everything completed — and it turned out to be one of the best gaming experiences I’ve had in a long time.

The story is incredible, the characters feel real, and Night City is insanely immersive. Every mission feels meaningful, and the freedom in gameplay lets you approach things however you want. I was genuinely invested from start to finish.

I did experience some crashes from time to time, but nothing that ruined the overall experience.

Amazing world, strong story, tons of content, and huge replay value.
Highly recommended.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Battlefield™ 2042".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I played Battlefield 2042 with a buddy for a few months at launch, and despite the game being extremely buggy and the vehicles being wildly overpowered, that chaos was a big part of the fun. The early experience delivered unpredictable moments and ridiculous vehicle plays that everyone loved, even if it wasn’t polished.

A few months later the patches toned things down. The vehicle changes removed a lot of that launch-era craziness, and while the gunplay was decent, it felt more arcade-like and less true to classic Battlefield roots. After that, I stepped away from the game for about a year.

Coming back right before BF6 released, the game was in a much better place. It felt more balanced, more stable, and surprisingly captured the Battlefield vibe well enough to hold me over until the next game dropped. Overall, Battlefield 2042 became a solid stepping stone for the series—rough start, but it eventually grew into a fun, respectable experience.

Before the Armor 2.0 update payday3 was decent - it wasnt super bad, just kinda easy, repetitive and a bit boring after some time,
But now after the update and the recent balance changes, payday3 finally is enjoyable and actually fun to play.
Armor 2.0 is much better than the old armor, providing more variety to builds.

They finally added an option to have different outfits for different builds.
Stealth is (and was) much better than in payday2.
Loud, after the recent update, is finally great and somewhat challenging - snipers now actually shoot, naders throw their grenades (and actually throw them much better and more often than before), cops finally deal damage etc
The OG heists are great, the newer ones aren't much worse
And the newest Powder Party heist gives payday2s Shadow raid heist vibes, which in my opinion is great.
One thing - please add something like payday2s infamy system, it would really help the game and its progression
and maybe rework the shop so the primary weapons and secondaries are in separate categories

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion: Cyberpunk 2077 surprised me in a good way. When I first played it, it felt unfinished and I was honestly a bit disappointed, especially given all the hype. I played it through once and then stopped. I went back to it about a year or so later and found it had improved massively. Night City feels alive and full of personality, and I found myself just cruising around and taking it all in. The story pulled me in more than I expected, with some genuinely great characters and moments that stick with you. The gameplay is decent and gives you plenty of different ways to complete missions. I’ve found that character skills also play a big role in how the game plays. Visually, the game looks great, especially at night. One of my main gripes is that the NPCs feel a little lacking compared to some other games, but that’s relatively minor. In the end, it turned into an amazing game and I’m glad I gave it another go.

completion:
December 27th 2025:
I still dont recommend the game in its current state but its on the right track. The fact Starbreeze is release paid DLC for an incomplete game is wild to me, but it just feels in line with what we have come to expected from companies now a days.

The game can be very fun, but the original heists are so tiny and rubbish, that you NEED to buy the DLC ones to get enjoyment from the game. 

Would still recommend PD2 over this. 

May 12th 2024:
Only reason I didnt refund the game was because Im holding out Starbreeze will start listening to the community and fix the game. 

If this game interests you then dont buy it, buy Pay Day 2 instead will all the DLC, its a more fleshed out game with better content. Even the earlier missions of PD2 are better than any mission in PD3. Maps feel smaller and less interesting/fleshed out than PD2 maps. Missions are basically all the exact same BS with no character to them.

This game feels like they took everything great about the Pay Day series and threw it out the window to modernize it. 
Unless they fix the game and gameplay, Id stay 100ft away

Fantastic game, and I do recommend it with a caveat:

There appears to be a broad issue with the game stuttering at various times and various length of times which can make or break the game for people.  This isn't an isolated case, a search online will show it's been an ongoing problem for years.  Many players have offered different solutions which work for some players but not for others.  Unfortunately I'm one one of the players none of these solutions have worked and will be unable to complete the game due to it.

But because the game is as good as it is, I'm marking as a recommendation, but people need to be aware of the risk involved that it might be unplayable.

Review:
completion:
Listen well, fellow Tarnished
for I speak not with arrogance… but with certainty.

I have fallen.
I have bled.
I have stood before foes who thought themselves gods.

And yet
I am still here.

The Lands Between test us with blades, with sorcery, with despair itself. They whisper that we are unworthy, that we were cast out for a reason. But tell me this

Who decided that?

Was it the gods who hid behind thrones?
Was it fate, trembling at our approach?

No.

For every time death claimed me, I rose.
Every time the world said kneel, I stood taller.
Not because I was chosen
but because I refused to yield.

Fear?
I acknowledge it… and walk past it.

Failure?
It sharpens me.

Gods?
If they stand in my path
then they will learn what it means to face a Tarnished who does not bow.

Remember this, my fellow Tarnished:

You do not challenge the Erdtree because you are strong.
You are strong because you challenge it.

Stand proud.
Carry your scars like crowns.
And if the world dares ask who you are

Tell them:

I am no pawn of fate, no servant of gods.
I walk where the world fears to tread,
and in my steps, I carve the ending itself.

Needed an AI help for things that I want to add for NORMAL difficulties like a 9to5 worker like me :'( (I know my life is miserable).
Lost Ark is a great game but I would like to say:
The Need for Solo Legion Raids:

Smilegate RPG has undoubtedly crafted a masterpiece with Lost Ark, catering to both solo players and group enthusiasts alike. However, the absence of single-player legion raids for normal difficulties could be a missed opportunity. Implementing this feature would address the desires of players who prefer to experience content solo without compromising the existing group raid mechanics.

Adding single-player legion raids on normal difficulties would also benefit new players who may be hesitant to engage in group content early on. It would serve as a stepping stone, allowing them to hone their skills, learn raid mechanics, and gear up before venturing into more challenging group raids.

Furthermore, solo legion raids could offer an alternative way for players to experience the lore and unique encounters at their own pace, providing additional depth and engagement to the game's solo gameplay.

Write a negative Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
(My Steam hours are low, but I played 60+ hours on Xbox Game Pass.)

Payday... where to begin? Payday: The Heist on PS3 was an absolute banger, and Payday 2 became one of the best co-op shooters of all time. I own most of the DLC, have over 100 hours across flat screen and VR, and it’s been nothing but excellence. Then came Payday 3…

To say I’m disappointed is an understatement. Starbreeze had the chance to deliver one of the greatest sequels ever, but fell short in almost every way. Day 1 was a mess — constant issues, online only restrictions, and unstable servers. The map selection was tiny and mechanics were janky. Now in 2025, little has changed. Instead of meaningful content, we’ve seen pathetic DLCs dropping and almost no substantial updates.

Payday 3 feels less like a sequel and more like a downgrade. Unless something drastic changes, I don’t see Starbreeze recovering from this monumental failure.

If your looking for a new adventure - Look further not here. 

Graphics - Are what got me into this game. 
But the Endgame is so - Lackluster its just an eye sore to even want to jump on after this week. 
Heres my experience. 
The storyline is great - but you get to the end and their so called (BIG CONTENT EXPANSIONS) are just a single story and mission playthrough.

You cant get experience in anything because you cant find a group in it. 
Everyone wants to bill you to run it for you but even then how they want you to pay for it is buying something in the market for a certain price and they run it.

The dailys get repetative SUPER quick. 
Everythings got its limit of how much you can do of it is farming is extremely limited. 
And the public events are so dead the only one you can run is the twisted demon portal. 
And EVEN THAT EVENT is only like 3-5 minutes TOPS. 

Its hard to stay motivated in a game where the ONLY content you have is achievement based. 

Give me Diablo 4 with Lost Ark Skill Graphics and maybe we got something there.

prompt:

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
GTA San Andreas is an all-time classic. I played it years ago, and now I came back to it – with improved graphics and some tweaks, it feels way better. The visual upgrades really help, everything looks cleaner and smoother without losing that old-school vibe.

The story still hits, the gangsta atmosphere in Los Santos is as fun as ever, and the missions are just as good as I remembered. Gameplay holds up surprisingly well even after all these years. Throw in a few mods, and you’ve got something legendary.

If you played it before, it’s definitely worth coming back to. And if you’ve never played it – what the hell are you doing? This is a piece of gaming history.

Still one of my favorite games of all time. Fully recommend it.

After Completing This Game On Ultra Settings On My Rtx 4050, I Am Really Impressed How Smooth It Ran Upto 100+ Fps. 
The Main Problem Is If You Unlocked The Fps You Are Gonna Face Cutscenes Softlock Or Glitches. In Key To Her Heart Mission, Millie's Ai Will Broke Inside The House And She Will Not Approach Cj Until You Cap The Fps To 30, Second Problem Is In Meat Business Mission Where The Sindacco Goon Will Stand Still Instead Of Throwing The Molotov Cocktail Which Just Softlocks The Game, Third Is The Boat School Because Of Higher Frames The Vortex Spawn And Sink Without Any Reason Which Leads The Players To Death. And There Is Another Bug, I Don't Know Why This Keeps Happening In My Game, Homies Can't Enter Vehicle At Certain Times, Doors Seems Locked To Them, This Bug Wasn't In The Original Though.
This Was My Experience After Completing This Game Fully.

Do I Recommend This Game?
Well If You Ask Me Then Yes Just To Revisit Our Childhood In Shiny Graphics.

Just a few different sets that get bigger stats with honing. The game gets really bad at end game. Its just running the same thing over on several characters then logging off. Review:
completion:
I had been waiting for this game to come to the West since it was first announced. I took off from work, got all my buddies to play....

And was immediately let down. I was expecting a long story campaign, and it was long alright, but for all the wrong reasons. It was just a janky mess, with busted cut scenes, 1hp open world enemies and 1M hp dungeon enemies. It was constant whiplash.

Then you get to the the meat of the content, the repeatable stuff you do for gear... and it's just BAD. It never explains anything to you. Just "okay, this is unlocked now, have fun!" 

Every inch of this game is pay to win garbage. Covered in content designed to be not fun unless you pay for stuff.

And lets not get started on the "community" around this game. Almost worse than League Players. In the earliest trials, there were people rage quitting groups because someone didn't know the mechanics ON THEIR VERY FIRST RUN. Also like 40% of the players are just bots. For most of my time playing the game I ran into more bots than people, and the people I did run into were incredibly toxic and nasty.

DO yourself a favor and stay away, the cool combat isn't worth the rest of everything.

For me, this is the best GTA ever when it comes to story. CJ’s whole journey, the family drama, the gang stuff, it all just hits different. There are so many moments that stick with me even after all these years.

Even though it’s an old game, the Definitive Edition makes it feel fresh again without losing what made it special in the first place. To me, it’s still unbeatable.

Warning: real-money purchases can be deleted without refund

I spent ~30€ via Steam on Blue Crystals in Lost Ark, used on the IGNITE server (an official catch-up event). Later, I didn’t migrate my character — and all items I bought with real money were deleted without warning.

At no point during purchase or in-game did it say these items would be lost if I didn’t transfer. Support refused any refund or restoration and even threatened “sanctions” for asking again.

I’ve filed a complaint through SignalConso (French consumer protection). This violates EU digital content law — paid items can’t be removed without clear prior notice.

If you value your purchases, be very careful spending real money in this game.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "ELDEN RING".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Really enjoy the game. I play it on a laptop not meant for gaming and so there was the added difficulty of a pretty bad pc port which has very slow input lag and control drift, in addition to stuttering and whatnot, but enemies and bosses are mostly doable as long as they are predictable. Once I got a controller, everything became much easier due to more responsive controls and whatnot, even on this potato laptop.

Some critiques:
1. Some of the level and arena designs are quite poor in that they present difficulties unrelated to the game mechanics but are purely technical such as giant bosses in tiny arenas which lead to cameras constantly clipping into the walls and the boss itself
2. These poor design issues combine with poor controls to create situations where you are really fighting against your own PC and camera rather than the boss itself, which can be a challenge in itself but not the enjoyable point of this game.

All in all, still a very enjoyable game with an actual challenge.

Fun to try out. Would recommend for that.

Wow, this game is a hot mess. So many things lost from Payday 2 when coming into this game, you question what's the point of a sequel when it has less content and its worse overall.

I won't go into detail given the countless negative reviews commenting on how this game sucks, so I'll just comment on my least favorite aspect of this game.

The cop animations are vastly inferior than Payday 2. In that game, cops reacted in a multitude of ways depending of the angles they're shot from. They would occasionally trip and fall, spending time to regain their footing. If shot on the back, they would throw their arms in surprise and fall forward. They even have an unique animation if you shot them in the balls. That energy is sorely missing in Payday 3. They brush off bullets as if they were airsoft pallets. They don't even throw themselves on the floor anymore to escape line of fire, they just occasionally sidestep and ragdoll on death.

No matter how much they rework Payday 3's skill or armor system like how they've been trying to do for over two years (holy fuck), this level of detail and energy on the cops is something we'll never see again.

And it is the most accessible game yet, although for a newcomer, it WILL still be challenging.

It's honestly one of my favorite games of all time, for everything. The lore, the gameplay, the worldbuilding, the level design, the characters, the music... Everything is so damn good.

And the message has always been the same in their games.

With patience and determination... you WILL get better. Not only better at the game... but also better than yourself.

completion: The learning curve is brutal if you've never played a Souls game before. You. Must. Learn. To. Dodge. By rolling and jumping. And when fighting big bosses, don't get greedy with your attacks like in other games. Also, understand that different weapons and sorceries/incantations have better effects against some enemies rather than others. There's no one-size-fits-all in this game. Once you get the mechanics down, the adventuring, storyline and gameplay is very rewarding.

Review:
completion:
stop before it's too late

In order to keep up-to-date on content, game relies on you sustaining a 6 character "main" roster, each with 5-30minutes of daily content, and 1-3 gold-earning raids, each ranging from 5 minutes to 2 hours long, depending on how overgeared the 4-8 players in the raid are.

You earn gold through selling your tradeable dropped materials in daily content, but the bulk of your gold earning is through running your gold-earning raids on 6 different characters.

The most recent content as of this review, Hard Mode Brelshaza, can take a minimum of 45 minutes to clear all 6 gates with everyone well overgeared for the content. However, the 5th and 6th gates individually can take hours for pug group if raid wipes are constantly triggered. 15 minutes of raid time just wasted if the last few mechanics are failed.

Review:
completion:
Elden Ring feels like a game made with real passion. It doesn’t rush you or tell you exactly what to do, you free to explore, get lost, and learn at your own pace. The world is beautiful but also stressful, and every new area feels exciting to discover.
The combat is hard, but in a good way. When you finally beat a tough enemy, it feels incredibly satisfying. The story is quiet and mysterious, which makes you want to keep playing and figure things out yourself.
Overall, Elden Ring isn’t just fun, it feels rewarding. It challenges you, tests your patience, and gives you a strong sense of achievement when you push through..

Review:
completion: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2023 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The game uses a modern, GTA V-style control scheme, which makes shooting and driving much easier than in the original.

The original story, characters, and massive open world of San Andreas are still fantastic and hold up well today.

The game is massive, with three cities, a huge countryside, and tons of missions, side activities, and RPG elements.

The story of CJ and the Grove Street Families is iconic and filled with memorable characters.
