Review:
completion:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
"Childhood Chaos, Now in HD — And Yes, I Still Rode a Bike for 3 Hours"

GTA: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition is the glow-up of my reckless teenage years. The graphics? Smoother. The city? Bigger than my attention span. The nostalgia? Hits harder than Big Smoke’s order at Cluckin’ Bell.

You play as CJ, a man who just wanted to go home but instead got dragged into a whirlwind of gang wars, corrupt cops, and driving across the entire state just to deliver a pizza. It’s freedom, chaos, and comedy rolled into one—basically a life simulator if your life included jetpacks and chainsaws.

The remaster makes everything look cleaner, but the heart of San Andreas is still the same: stealing cars, ignoring the main story for hours, and wondering if you should go to the gym or just eat 40 burgers. Spoiler: it’s the burgers.

By the time I finished, I wasn’t just playing a game—I was reliving a piece of gaming history. It’s the rare remaster that makes you feel like a kid again while still reminding you that you’re way worse at flying planes than you remembered.

10/10. Would shout “GROVE STREET, HOME!” every time I boot it up.

Review:
completion:
Battlefield 2042 is a good game. But it is one of if not the worst Battlefields of them all.
A good portion of the maps are wide open, making camping with snipers the only playstyle that is actually viable. 
That being said, the idea of weather effects really creates some unique experiences.
Weapons are average at best. Most of the guns you'll encounter are meta weapons since they really have a big advantage over some of the weaker guns. Take the PP as an example.
Play this game if you like large scale battles. But consider spending a bit more and just buy Battlefield 6 if you want a more 'classic' Battlefield experience

[h1]Overall[/h1]
This game is long-term game. 
You definitely would have to invest a some amount of time and consistency to play for fun.
(not like 100 hours or 300 hours)

It does require pretty expensive rig. 
Unlike League of Legends, and WOW, this game has a lot of in-game features and particles to render.
You may be required a computer with high specifications for playable quality.

[h1]Currency[/h1]
After spending around a couple hundreds of dollars (mostly Ark-pass, monthly buffs, and skins), I can tell this game is clearly playable as F2P. 
It's your choice to spend an amount of money to become stronger quick. 
However, in the end, everyone will be in a similar level (unless you decided to dump a car in it).

[h1]Newcomers[/h1]
For newcomers, I would recommend start playing whenever there is a major event (such as Super Mokoko Express, etc.).
and try enjoying the stories (some of them are actually impressive).
I personally better recommend to play with friend who's been playing for quite awhile.

*PLEASE*
If you have any question while playing game, google it, ask in-game chat, or post question in the official LostArk Discord server.
(https://discord.gg/lostark)

prompt:
You are a regular Steam user.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Lost Ark".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Lost Ark has the best raids and combat/class gameplay of any raiding MMO. This is definitely a flawed game with p2w but long-time players play despite the issues because the raid gameplay is just that good. The other parts of the game will provide a few hundred hours of gameplay but they're not nearly as engaging as the raids. 

Many of the problems that plagued Lost Ark in its early years have been alleviated or solved. For example, chaos dungeons and guardian raids are only once a day, raids are generally only two gates (compared to the old Brelshaza raid that had 6 gates), and alts aren't necessary to play the latest raids. However, the content is timegated weekly so people typically make more alts to play more. Gatekeeping is still present but is alleviated for new/returning players with the mokoko bootcamp that gives veteran players an incentive to bring newbies to raids. There are also revives available in raids and progressive nerfs to raid boss HP/damage so the pressure during week to week reclearing has been greatly reduced.

Now is a great time to start or return to the game with the recent progression events and Paradise system that aids progression.

Review:
completion:
Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition is a pretty good game

+Graphics(It really looks good in terms of graphics, just like GTA 3 and Vice City.)
+Gameplay(The gameplay mechanics are the same, but like GTA 3 and Vice City, you can choose between modern or classic.)
+Story(the story is the same, only now the cutscenes are much more detailed)
+Open World(The world is much more detailed and seems to have more life, especially with the classic lighting that has been reintroduced.)

Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition is the last in the classic trilogy, remade with modern graphics, and the story in this game is very well told.

In some places they managed to fix this version, but as I said, the rest of the trilogy still needs patches.

In conclusion, a good trilogy that suffered a lot due to bad releases and managed to ruin its reputation.

But now this trilogy is being repaired.

10/10 Must Play! I recommend buying at a discount.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:

- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I can't give this a thumbs down because of how good everything else is, but I take issue with the RPG elements. There are plenty of half baked synergies presented to the player but in truth there are only a handful of viable builds. So many are distractions that should be ignored. Stacking a 2.5% bonus, or in some cases 0.05% bonus 5 times does not present an opportunity to base your build on that. Same goes for "cool" sounding combat loops that are impractical for 90% of scenarios.  For instance if there are mitigation perks & bonuses then I expect to construct a full build around mitigation and if I stack everything correctly it should be as powerful as having full armour + max health. 

The synergies are too weak, and most wearable items DO NOT PLAY INTO IT AT ALL!!. Missed opportunity to say the least. Ridiculous. Learn from games like Underrail where they got everything right.

By end game you can end up having 15+ in all attributes which cheapens your RPG efforts. 

Also do not appreciate the overall dystopian & unrealistic presentation of a corp led world, but that could be source material related.

Music is also pretty bad, only like 5 good tracks on the radio.

Overall I would say the gameplay up until endgame is pretty good! The story, while kinda goofy is enjoyable in some parts!

My only real gripe with the game is honing is the progression system and boy is it aggrivating, if you don't wanna spend money you gotta grind for a few days to attempt to hone an item. Oh it's like a 2% chance to upgrade? well pony up some cash or keep grinding. It sucks that f2p is so held back but I understand it's the play model they're choosing. 

Overall it's a 5/10 great boss fights and fun mechs but the end game progression sucks. Perhaps it's changed but with POE2 out I don't see a reason to go back.

Overall 8.5/10

Watching the evolution of PAYDAY 2 and how the story ended was definitely gonna set the bar high for PAYDAY 3.
This game had a VERY rough start. Literally unplayable during the day due to the amount of people and the fact they made it online only.
It's taken a little bit but I haven't had any issues lately and the game isn't super buggy.

My only real negative about the game is that sometimes objectives are kinda obscure when they should be right in front of you. It took me like 20 minutes to find the box to lower the bollards (i forgot which mission) when it should've been fairly obvious with the amount of action taking away from being able to search for it.

But the game is super fun, not quite up to par with what we expected of a PAYDAY 2 successor but the heists are engaging, the game feels good, everyone misses Bain but he had a good send off and Shade seems like a good stand in.


 AND THEY BROUGHT BACK WOLF

Finally got hooked and it was a hell of a ride start to finish. Loved the experience, and I may do more playthroughs in the future just to make different decisions and see the outcomes.

Sad that I couldn't get into it when it came out (even if it launched in a horrendous state), but I'm happy to have finally experienced what Night City had to offer.

Absolute must-play.

The legendary San Andreas...

The story here (without a doubt) is the best out of the trilogy.
Visuals after the update are amazing and faithful to the original version on PS2, but there's still some things missing like the motion blur effect when going too fast.
Gameplay is the worst part of this game, especially because of the bugs present here. Tbf they're very minimal compared to how they were on release.

Still a good way to experience this legendary game, you'll have plenty of fun.

As far as the game is concerned, its deep and I really value the commitment the developers put in to make it one of the best games I have ever played.  CD Project Red is fantastic.

Review:
completion:
So we start with the PC port coming from the PS2, then we have a mobile port done by devs who have no idea what they're doing, then we have a PC port based on THAT mobile version by the same devs (no longer credited btw).

This trilogy is a disgrace to humanity; most of the positive reviews didn't even play past Los Santos.

The definitive edition is an overexpensive coat of paint over an old engine (it's actually true, it's still using the old Renderware engine, but the visuals are handled by Unreal Engine).

Physics are broken, no super sprint, swimming is slow. (Funny enough, fixed on the mobile DE version but no luck for PC gamers!)

Unless you're REALLY interested in achievements, just get yourself the original, downgrade the game if needed, and add the community fixes (SilentPatch, Widescreen, Framerate Vigilante, etc.) and your experience will be MILES better.

Review:
completion:
One of the best action RPG ever made that is even better than the Dark Souls trilogy (imo) because it's open world, making the feeling of discovery constant. The level design is genius. You don’t just walk across a map; you scale jagged peaks, descend into rotting catacombs, and traverse floating ruins. Every time you think you’ve seen it all, you find a hidden elevator that leads to a starlit underground city or a secret path that opens up a continent-sized region you didn't know existed.

Build wise, the experimentation is pretty much endless as well. Whether you want to be a hulking knight with a slab of iron, a cosmic pew-pew sorcerer raining stars from the sky, a nimble samurai or a Bonk Boi with a massive hammer, the game has something for you.

My verdict : Masterpiece out of 10. You need to play this.

Review:
completion:
Despite the game's shortcomings since release, There's surprisingly a pretty good amount of genuinely good improvements from the transition from Payday 2 to 3 (and yes, I count the lack of the H3H3 heisters to be a blessing.) 

When I initially played the beta (or atleast, as much as I could've with the hardware I had at the time) it felt underwhelming. I won't deny that Payday 3 still needs more time, but after catching it on sale... I figured I'd give it a shot, and surprisingly the year I turned my interest away from Payday as a whole ended up making this game somewhat enjoyable. Janky, but quite enjoyable. 

While I miss Simon Viklund's music, Gustavo really was allowed to cook, and man am I here for it! 
For the time being, I give the game a 6/10. Some may view the game as a disappointment, but Payday 2 didn't exactly have a great track record for a long while after release, so I'm going to sit back and do what the Cook Off Soundtrack says to do: Let Them Cook.

completion:
Finally got the build to play it and the time to start it.

Just finished the first Chapter and oh my... I've never seen a game talk so well with its background music. The overall aesthetic and feeling of what is to come left me speechless so many times during the playthrough so far. Night City is astonishing and really feel like one day I will explore each corner of all the buildings just for fun.

I don't know what else to add considering I am still at the beginning of the story but I really loved each moment. What left a huge hole is the Isometric Air soundtrack that plays right before the Konpeki Plaza heist. Since the first second I was in the car with Jackie and heard it I knew something big was about to happen. Then heard it again during the elevator scene and all I wanted is to go outside on the balcony and listen to it while admiring the view. Haven't had such a feeling in a long while. Good job, CDPR. Really exceeded any kind of expectation I had.

completion:
Cyberpunk 2077 had a rocky start for me. I preordered it on PS4 at launch, and it was a mess,bugs everywhere, performance issues, and I quickly thought it was a flop.

A few years later, I gave it another shot on PC, andwhat a difference. Not only did it run smoothly, but CD Projekt Red patched it so well that i could no longer see any cracks. The world is incredible, with deep lore, insane humor, and moments that genuinely made me stop and think, “Wow…this is one of those games.” 

After all the patches and updates, this game went from disappointment to an absolute must-play.

prompt:

Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I pre-ordered Battlefield 2042, and to say I was disappointed at launch would be an understatement. The game felt unfinished and directionless. But as time went on and the developers kept updating it, the experience slowly started to grow on me. While it never reached the memorable heights of Battlefield 3 or Battlefield 4, 2042 eventually found its footing. Still, it always felt like the odd one out, kind of like Battlefield Hardline. Now that it’s reached the end of its life cycle, I can say Battlefield 2042 served its purpose. It was never meant to be the next great Battlefield, even though it was hyped as one. In the end, it feels more like a stepping stonea placeholder that gave DICE time to prepare for what fans truly wanted, which we’re finally getting with Battlefield 6.
 2042 ended up being... alright. Not great, not terrible, just a chapter in Battlefield’s evolution.

completion:
[b] Battlefield 2042 [/b] is a strong shooter for people who want something different from typical Call of Duty or Counter-Strike. There are not many maps, but each one has its own unique atmosphere and style of fighting, so the game never gets boring. Besides, there is a nice solo mode for players who like to play calmly and practice.

The gameplay is fast, intense, and not predictable. There is always something happening on the maps. Some fight inside buildings, others drive tanks or fly helicopters. The fights are strong, and the situation can change in a few seconds. Sometimes the weather makes it hard to see or forces players to move, which makes the game more exciting. The game gives a lot of freedom. You can play aggressively, help your team, or act alone. It all depends on the player's style and the chosen specialist.

Is it worth it? Definitely yes.

The basic combat mechanics and raid design in this game is unmatched.  10/10.

The world, collectibles, and story are largely pointless window dressing for me though I'm sure some that enjoy it.

The way they make you grind in order to do the fun new raids is borderline abusive.  But its either that or swiping the credit card.  I stopped playing for a month while travelling and felt so much better without that constant need to keep up - haven't logged in since and am happier for it.  

Of the 2400 hours I played.  I'd guess that 400 of those were progging new, interesting bosses with friends and was some of the most fun I've ever had gaming.  The other 2000 hours were largely pointless busy work that I'm embarrassed to have sunk into the game.

Worst Battlefield game I've ever had the displeasure of playing. The only fun I had was in a heavily modified custom mode I made using Portal -- and even that was subpar. Even getting it on sale for $3 felt like too much for this trash.

I do have to thank this game for one thing, however: If it hadn't been such complete and utter garbage -- so much so that it nearly killed the franchise -- Battlefield 6 wouldn't be as good as it is.

- bots

- gatekeeping

I’ve played a ton of Payday 2, and right now it still has a lot more content and variety than Payday 3.
That said, the new game has solid foundations: the gunplay feels good, the heists with friends are fun, and it looks much better.

There are still quite a few issues though.. audio bugs, crashes, weird enemy behavior and not enough content compared to the previous game. I really hope the devs roll out big updates soon to fix bugs and add more missions and customization.

For now I can’t give it more than 6.5/10, but with the right support it could grow a lot.

A lot of people are quick to blame the game, but they're overclocking, running beta drivers, or questionable background software. Most of that stuff literally warns you it might cause crashes. Yet somehow it's always the game's fault?

Dota 2 is probably the best online game I've ever played. I've been playing Dota 1, both online and offline, and it took some time before I tried Dota 2. But when I tried Dota 2, I immediately decided to stick with the game.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "PAYDAY 3".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
PD2 veteran here.

Didn't really like the way they approached Payday 3. I liked the crazy cracked builds and hostage takers, broken ass passives, active skills etc. The skills and the passives are REALLY dumbed down here. Like there is literally no depth. But the swap from the abomination that was the Diesel engine to a proper game engine that can handle... you know... GUNS feels like a fever dream. They feel awesome, animations are snappy and thonky. The hitreg is awesome. Cops don't have 2 animations for being hit. The hitmarkers are very clean which helps the hit feel a lot. 

I hated stealth. I still do. But this game, they made it so much more interesting with a brand new gadget slot, unmasked gameplay, several new interaction animations, CQC with hostage grabbing etc. Makes for some fun times. I still go loud as soon as I can tho.

Be mindful that i got the game and a few dlc's on a massive discount, it made me remember the good old times and hope for its better future. I still want to go back and play Payday 2 but god forbid that game engine. Do me a solid one Overkill and cook a great game. You have good potential.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "ELDEN RING".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
For anyone who likes carving out a path in the wild or tackling formidable challenges, Elden Ring is undoubtedly worth playing. The open world is massive and bristling with life in a way that makes respect for nature hard to avoid. And there's always something fun waiting around the corner: a new area to explore, an alien boss that kicks your ass

The fighting is real severe at the beginning, but when you figure it out, everything is very satisfying. Every victory feels liike it was earned through sweat and blood, which can be rewarding in its own way. The bosses are memorable, the atmosphere is amazing and it is nice to realize that a game doesn't punish you just for asking questions

But it's definitely not for everyone. If you don't appreciate ultra hard games the way some people don't mind cutting off their noses to spite their faces (I have fun with these folks) then Elden Ring is a hard sell. However, if you're a challenging open-world gamer who digs the world or likes a good line of dialogue just as much as I do, this has got to be one of your most enjoyable experiences

But I wish Valve wasn't JUST milking it for its money and actually released gameplay content instead of a constant flow of hats, unusual effects and weapon skins. There has been a map bloat in recent times as well... (And its not like Valve themselves makes ANY of this cosmetic and map content)

Though not many current TF2 players know this, but there used to be a "quick play" system to easily find and play matches, with preference options and even an option to include community servers. It was all removed in favour of "Casual", where matches can start with 3-6 players on each team (instead of the nearly full 12v12 lobbies), or you could join a match that has already ended, or have no option to avoid a steam roll (You used to be able to change teams and also call a vote to scramble teams to even out the odds!), and lastly, the matches can last less than 5 minutes before sending you into another long loading screen...

I would love to change my rating because this is genuinely one of the best FPS shooters out there, but I can't condone what Valve is doing, clearly knowing they can get away with as little content as possible while earning tons of money.

[h1]Rating: 9.2/10[/h1]

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
This game was my first souls-like. The cinematics and cutscenes are upper echelon, the scenery is peak, and you can tell the entirety of everything was well thought out. From emerging through a tunnel and seeing the sacred Erdtree in perfect view, to killing a boss after an unholy amount of attempts, to finding the most niche easter egg, Elden Ring can easily have you busy for THOUSANDS of hours.

This is a game I recommend playing at your own pace, in your own style, because the first playthrough will be your most memorable by a landslide.

That being said, I know the whole point of this vague, open world game is to allow you to have your own adventure, but I think a quest log of some sort wouldn't hurt just to provide a bit of organization and prevent players from skipping out on content.

All in all, a very memorable gaming experience that I could see a wide variety of gamers enjoying whether they be more casual or hardcore.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Team Fortress 2".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
This game is (almost) a gold standard of balance that can hold both the test of time and extreme conditions. Community tinkering and experience have pushed this game so far and the depth of the game means that almost 18 (!) years later the playerbase is still kicking and rabid as ever.

There's not much that can be said about this game that hasn't been discussed at least 3 times over, however I will still point out one of the flaws that strikes the hardest to me, that being the weapon balance.

The stock classes themselves are fine and show a lot of tweaking and thought into their designs, however some items that were added after initial release do not show this consideration, such as the Homewrecker for Pyro, the Vaccinator for Medic and also some of the weaker weapons like Sun on a Stick for Scout, Red Tape Recorder for Spy or the Eviction Notice for Heavy.

This game overall is great though, and many criticisms about game balance were unanticipated on Valve's part or are tied into the map design of popular maps added by the community.

Review:
completion:
Nostalgic but Honest" (Balanced)

Headline: Still the best story, even if the coat of paint is a bit messy.

Look, we all know the original San Andreas is a masterpiece. This version is the easiest way to play it on modern hardware without spending hours modding it, but it’s definitely not perfect.

The Good: The controls are much better—they finally added a "weapon wheel" and modernized the aiming so it feels more like GTA V. The lighting at sunset looks genuinely great, and having GPS on the mini-map is a lifesaver.

The Bad: Some of the character models still look a bit "off" (almost like clay figures), and they took out some of the iconic fog that made the map feel bigger. There are still occasional bugs, though most of the game-breaking ones from launch are gone.

Verdict: Buy it on sale. It’s still CJ, it’s still Grove Street, and the radio stations still slap. Just don't expect a full remake.

Masterpiece.

A game that doesn't need to be described. In other words, I really don’t need to convince you to buy it.

But, in case you are one of those suspicious people, I’ve made a list for you:

- Have you ever heard about The Odyssey? Yes, the ancient greek story? Never mind, this one is better.

- Ever heard about John Williams? Yes, the composer of the Star Wars soundtrack. No? Whatever, the soundtrack from Michael Hunter in this game beats it.

- You may be thinking: “aw the game is old! Graphics must suck!” Guess what? It was remastered, genius. It won’t be like a Da Vinci painting, but who cares?

- Aircrafts, boats, cars to customize, guns, minigun, RPG, gang wars, a huge map with a CASINO and GYMS where you can get RIPPED or learn KARATE! What else do you want?

Name it! This game has everything you can imagine when you think about a Grand Theft Auto.

Cons: You have to pay for it. Don’t be a cheapskate.

I really hope you buy it. I can assure you it's 100% worth it.

You know what, BF 2042's not as bad as folks made it out to be.  

Sure, it's absolutely on the COD-twitchfest side of gunplay and rewards more manic movements instead of tactical movement/positioning and such, and it took a bunch of updates and gameplay overhauls to reach this point, but I actually enjoyed myself while playing and grinding the free season pass leading up to BF6's release. 

It's obviously not a wise idea to grab this game at full price anymore though, especially since BF6 will no doubt absorb most of the playerbase and leave its servers considerably empty.  But if you happen to see a steep discount and wanna recreate those meme "Only In Battlefield" stunts, or like comp-stomping the AI bots?  Might not be too bad of a purchase.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas – The Definitive Edition".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
These remakes bring a lot of quality of life improvements that you wish were in the original, but it's far from the perfect experience many people seem to be expecting. And I can sympathize, asking $20 per game for titles that are 20 years old now, you'd expect some more polish and fixes in most areas. However, this is still an older title that brings it up to compatibility for newer machines which I can appreciate. If I'm playing, I'm not really looking for out of place objects or paying attention to random texture glitches. For my playthrough (I'm at 88% completion on San Andreas), I didn't see or run into anything game breaking. In fact I would say it was a far more enjoyable experience than playing the original. I'm sure if you go out of your way to find them, you will indeed find flaws in the remake but personally that's not why I bought the games.

If you're just looking to play the original trilogy without having to deal with compatibility issues and having a more modern control feel, I can recommend this. If you're looking to play the original trilogy where everything is fixed and flawless, I would not bother.

Review:
completion:
However, the game still needs more fixes and updates. Bugs, glitches, and performance issues haven’t been fully eliminated, and some updates still break things instead of improving stability. There are also quality-of-life problems that the community has already solved through mods.

This is where the biggest issue comes in: mods. Fan-favorite mods and collections—especially large ones like the Welcome to Night City Nexus/Vortex collection—greatly improve visuals, immersion, UI, and gameplay. Many of these mods fix or enhance things the base game still struggles with. CD Projekt Red should seriously consider officially integrating or supporting popular community mods, or at least providing better tools so updates don’t constantly break them.

Cyberpunk 2077 has amazing potential and has come a long way, but it’s still not “finished.” More polish, long-term fixes, and better mod support would go a long way toward making this the definitive version of the game it was meant to be.

Man, San Andreas is one of those games that just never gets old. The first time I played it, I was hooked instantly. The story of CJ coming back home, dealing with family, gangs, and all the crazy stuff in between—it’s unforgettable. It feels gritty, fun, and full of personality.
 The map is massive (especially for its time). Driving through Los Santos, exploring the desert, or hitting up Las Venturas feels like you’re in a whole different world. There’s just so much freedom while doing missions, messing around, or just cruising with the king of cars SULTANNN <3
 Replayability? Endless. It's impossible to not come back after some time to replay it after you finish the game, like come on, it never feels boring.

MASTERPIECE 11/10

Review:
completion:
As someone who plays games for story and depth, and engaging gameplay, I think this game is fantastic! 
I don't really know much about the end game content or the general grind but I feel as a free-to-play game, they've done a great job and you can definitely get plenty hours of fun out of this no doubt! 
I will list some pros and cons based on my personal opinion.
Pros
- Decent graphics and not too demanding
- Fantastic fast paced action gameplay
- Engaging story campaign 
- Real-time cinematic cutscenes
- Good soundtrack
- Free-to-play

Cons
- Gender locked classes (meaning some genders are limited in advanced classes)
- Quite a lot of information early on can be overwhelming
- Limited inventory space that fills up very quickly

Overall I'd give this game an 8/10 and definitely worth giving it a try at the very least.
Happy gaming! :)

Review:
completion: Ahh yes... personally my first GTA that I really spent any considerable amount of time on. Yes when I was a kid.. I fell in love with San Andreas. I loved spending hours trying to find cheats and what not for the game. Talking with friends about it.. now to have the Definitive edition as an adult with adult money and time... I'm still in love with Los Santos. Even more so now that I have spent the last 10 years playing GTAV. Coming back to the roots of LS, seeing all the connections made, obvious improvements, hearing voice actors Rockstar has used in other titles from recent years in GTASA has been a smack of nostolgia. Of course there's the buggy gameplay in some points. but what do we really expect? I purchased on sale, and honestly.. just from only playing 13 hours at the point of review and only roughly 19% completed in ONLY GTASA.. yeah it's worth full price. Especially because you get GTA 3 and GTA Vice City in the bundle. If you're a hardcore GTA fanboy, must buy. Go relive your early days of picking up hookers and droppin bangers.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "ELDEN RING".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
Elden Ring is an incredible experience, its world is gorgeous, the atmosphere is unmatched, and the combat/build variety makes every playstyle feel viable. Exploring the Lands Between is constantly exciting, especially when you stumble into a hidden dungeon or a major boss fight that feels truly epic, but in the first 40-80 hours.
That said, the open world can feel oddly empty at times: long rides through beautiful scenery with little happening, and many caves/catacombs start to feel repetitive with reused enemies and layouts. Quests are also so cryptic that it’s easy to miss content without using guides. Even with these flaws, it’s still one of the most memorable action RPGs out there.
